headline: What channel is Man Utd vs Celtic legends on? Squad lists, time, TV and live stream, tickets
body: Two titans of European football will come together in support of the MU Foundation, with a team of Manchester United legends set to take on their Celtic counterparts
A team of Manchester United legends will stare down a side of Celtic icons at Old Trafford on Saturday.

Bryan Robson and Andy Cole have assembled a keen group of United superstars from down the years, with all proceeds going to the Manchester United Foundation. Meanwhile, Paul Lambert will call up a group of Bhoys icons to take on the challenge at the Theatre of Dreams.

Wayne Rooney, Paul Scholes and Dimitar Berbatov are just a few of the Old Trafford icons set to line up for the home side. However, a talented bunch have agreed to suit up for the charity clash, which will be available to watch on TV and via live stream.

Both clubs will be aiming to raise big sums, with the proceeds dedicated to helping young people across Manchester and further afield. Mirror Football provides all the need-to-know information ahead of Saturday's showdown, offering a welcome distraction to club football fans during the international break.

In addition to the aforementioned United trio of the not-too-distant past, Robson and Cole will also have the likes of Antonio Valencia, Danny Simpson, Michael Carrick, Darren Fletcher and Mikael Silvestre at their disposal. Celtic are yet to confirm a full list of players, per se, though Charlie Mulgrew, Stiliyan Petrov, Barry Robson and Jan Vennegoor of Hesselink are in line to feature.

Other Hoops icons like Georgios Samaras, Emilio Izaguirre, Artur Boruc, Jonny Hayes, Efe Ambrose, Stephen McManus, Joe Ledley, Mikael Lustig, Gary Hooper, Darren O’Dea, Simon Donnelly, Kelvin Wilson and Lukasz Zaluska are also believed to be in action. And former Aston Villa midfielder Petrov spoke of what the occasion means to him and his team-mates.

“I look forward to playing in these games and to see all those players again," he said prior to Saturday's showdown. "Not many of us see each other because everybody lives in different parts of the world, different places. So it’s a great pleasure to meet up again, share old stories, have a good laugh and enjoy a beer.

“I think both sets of fans will be expecting to win. Obviously Celtic now have a team that is a bit younger which is good. And you see that with the Dortmund game, it was very competitive, so I expect the same against Manchester United.”
Goalkeepers: Anders Lindegaard, Raimond van der Gouw, Kevin Pilkington
Defenders: Antonio Valencia, Danny Simpson, Phil Bardsley, Mikael Silvestre, Ronny Johnsen, Danny Pugh
Midfielders: Darren Fletcher, Paul Scholes, Karel Poborsky, Nicky Butt, Eric Djemba-Djemba, Michael Carrick, Chris Eagles, Luke Chadwick
Forwards: Fraizer Campbell, Danny Webber, Wayne Rooney, Dimitar Berbatov
United have unveiled their new adidas home kit with new front-of-shirt sponsors for the 2024/25 season - and you can get your hands on it right now.
Goalkeepers: Artur Boruc, Lukasz Zaluska
Defenders: Charlie Mulgrew, Darren O’Dea, Efe Ambrose, Kelvin Wilson, Mikael Lustig, Stephen McManus
Midfielders: Barry Robson, Joe Ledley, Jonny Hayes, Simon Donnelly, Stiliyan Petrov
Forwards: Gary Hooper, Georgios Samaras, Jan Vennegoor of Hesselink

Coverage of Saturday's match will get underway on MUTV at 1pm BST, though the game isn't due to kick off until 2pm. Alternatively, viewers can live stream this titanic encounter online via the MUTV website.
Tickets for Saturday's match are still available to purchase via either the official Manchester United website or through the MU Foundation.

headline: Man United news: Jurgen Klopp slams Jadon Sancho exit as Casemiro rejects transfer
body: There's still talk of exits from Manchester United, with a handful of clubs across Europe having longer to secure their signings before their transfer windows shut - after Erik ten Hag concluded his business with five big-name deals

Man United players have just jetted off for international duty and will hope to regroup stronger after ending their first three games with successive defeats - the last one being a 3-0 loss at home to Liverpool.

Some fans will still be optimistic of success this season after a string of impressive signings already, including young defender Leny Yoro, Dutch centre-back Matthijs de Ligt, PSG midfielder Manuel Ugarte and forward Joshua Zirkzee - with the new additions still needing time to settle in.
There's still talk of movements heading out of Old Trafford with a handful of clubs across Europe having extended periods before their transfer windows slam shut.
Mirror Football has rounded up all the latest news and developments around Old Trafford, including transfer reaction, rumours and gossip.

Former Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp is used to going toe-to-toe with Manchester United after nine years of plotting their downfall in the Premier League, but it appears he's not quite done with the rivalry after making a subtle jab over their decision to let go of Jadon Sancho.
The £73m England winger was loaned to Chelsea on deadline day with an obligation to buy after weeks of speculation, with the player unable to nail down regular first team football.
However, Klopp - who is currently without a club after leaving Liverpool in the summer - cannot understand why United and Ten Hag gave up on him so quickly.

"If the whole world loses trust and faith in the player, the manager has to be the one behind the player," he said prior to Sancho's deadline day switch. "I cannot just buy into that ‘he's useless,’ like other clubs did by the way - buying a player for £80 million and then sending him out on loan!"
Casemiro is one Man United player who has found himself in the crosshairs this season after his performances were questioned in the club's defeats to both Brighton and Liverpool.

There has even been talk the Brazilian could be offloaded to Turkey - with the country's window remaining open until September 13 - and Galatasaray are reportedly mulling over a deal, according to the Times.
But a further report from Turkish outlet Turkiye Gazetesi has claimed Galatasaray agreed to loan the player - who then rejected their advances because he wants to fight for his place at United.
France midfielder Adrien Rabiot is still looking for a new club after leaving Juventus as a free agent - which may come as a surprise given his pedigree and quality.

However, according to TEAMtalk, United remain among the clubs who are "in the mix" to snap up the Frenchman - along with Newcastle and Galatasaray. Free transfers can be signed at any time, but must be registered before the Premier League resumes on September 13 - but that can only happen if clubs have space in their squad lists.
This week, France boss Didier Deschamps said the situation was "embarrassing" for Rabiot after failing to find a club and said he could not recall him to the squad until he found a new team.

headline: Alan Shearer backs Jack Grealish to beat Arsenal and Man Utd stars to England role
body: Jack Grealish looks set to start for England in their Nations League clash with the Republic of Ireland in Dublin and Alan Shearer has had his say on the Man City star’s place with the Three Lions
Alan Shearer claims Jack Grealish has the perfect chance to lock down his England spot ahead of Marcus Rashford and Raheem Sterling.

The Manchester City star was included in Lee Carsley’s first Three Lions selection for upcoming Nations League clashes with the Republic of Ireland and Finland. Grealish’s inclusion signalled his first return to the England set-up since being left out of Gareth Southgate’s Euros squad.

And he is expected to start on Saturday, ironically against the side he turned away from before declaring for England. Shearer believes that if Grealish can hit top form during the current break, he could secure a Three Lions role for himself ahead of his left-wing rivals.
Shearer said: " Jack Grealish was named in the squad after saying himself that he was hugely disappointed not to be involved in the Euros. We know it was a bitter disappointment for him.

"For him to be named in the next squad, I think that tells you what Lee Carsley thinks of him and the belief he’s got in him. That should be a great confidence booster for Jack to think, ‘okay, this might be my time to step forward and take that left wing position’, when the likes of [Marcus] Rashford, [Raheem] Sterling and [Jadon] Sancho are all missing from the squad."
Grealish could be in for a somewhat unwelcome reception should he start in Dublin given his previous defection. His former teammate Callum Robinson is expecting boos during Saturday’s clash.
But Carsley has no concerns about throwing him straight in. Asked if he is worried about the reception he and Declan Rice could receive, he replied: “No, not at all.

“We spoke not only about Jack and Declan, but to the whole squad, we spoke about the atmosphere, we expect it to be exciting, passionate and loud. But it will be no different to what the players are used to in Premier League games or high-level games, so I think they will be ready for whatever comes out.”

Grealish, 28, has made 36 appearances during his England career but has scored just twice. His most recent appearance came in March this year in a 3-0 win against Bosnia & Herzegovina. The Manchester City man has not scored for the Three Lions since the opening match of the 2022 World Cup in Qatar - a 6-2 thumping of Iran.

headline: Harry Maguire to start with new England boss Lee Carsley to make FOUR major changes
body: The Manchester United defender missed the Euros and is no longer first choice at Old Trafford, but England interim boss Lee Carsley is set to hang his hat on the centre-back in Dublin
Harry Maguire has received a huge vote of confidence from Lee Carsley.

Manchester United defender Maguire did not make England’s squad for the Euros as he battled to overcome injury. Maguire, 31, did not start United’s last game with Liverpool either but Carsley is ready to start the big centre half in their Nations League showdown with Republic of Ireland.

England interim boss Carsley said: “He's a leader. He leads by example in terms of his preparation on and off the pitch. Obviously his quality is there to see as well when we do our sessions, so that's what I'm expecting to see.

“In the games that I've seen him play, I think he's got stronger as the games have gone on. Also, obviously, he didn't play in Manchester United’s last game, but he’s come into camp physically very, very good.
“And mentally, yeah, he's been good on and off the pitch I felt. What I want we've already had in terms of the way he's been around the squad, what I expected.”

‌Maguire looks set to partner Marc Guehi at the heart of defence with questions over John Stones ' fitness, while Trent Alexander-Arnold - after Gareth Southgate's failed midfield experiment at Euro 2024 - is likely to get the nod in his club position at right-back.
Both Anthony Gordon and Jack Grealish also look set to be given their heads in Dublin, Gordon having been frustrated by his Euros experience and Grealish having not gone at all.
Gordon told ITV : “I was disappointed, because I believe in myself so much. I feel unstoppable, especially at that point of the season I had just had.‌
“I felt like no-one could defend me, no-one could deal with me over 90 minutes. I felt like I was ready to and really impress people and help the country win the trophy.‌
“To envision what I envisioned… to what it was, it was disappointing.”
England Starting XI: Pickford; Alexander-Arnold, Guehi, Maguire, Colwill; Rice, Mainoo, Grealish; Saka, Gordon, Kane.

headline: Thomas Tuchel has made next move clear after reasons for Man Utd snub emerge
body: Former Bayern Munich manager Thomas Tuchel was heavily linked with the Manchester United job at the end of last season and he has made no secret of his love for the Premier League
Thomas Tuchel may not have landed the Manchester United job earlier this year, but the German has no secret of his desire to return to the Premier League.

It was announced back in February that Tuchel, 51, would leave his role as Bayern Munich head coach at the end of the 2023/24 campaign and he was subsequently touted for a number of high-profile roles.

Manchester United were one of said roles given the pressure Erik ten Hag was under towards the end of last season. And although Tuchel is known to have met with United chief Sir Jim Ratcliffe, he remains unattached.

Ten Hag was handed a contract extension off the back of an impressive triumph over Manchester City in last season's FA Cup final, but the Dutchman is already under siege following an underwhelming start to the current campaign.

That in turn has led to speculation over his future and reports recounting details between the talks which took place between Ten Hag and United. Bild claim that it was the club's transfer policy which led to Tuchel declining further talks.

While it remains to be seen if the top brass at Old Trafford would approach Tuchel again should they decide to dispense with Ten Hag's services in the coming weeks, the man himself has already opened the door for another spell in England.

During an interview back in May, Tuchel spoke fondly of his time at Chelsea - where he won the Champions League - and made it clear that he would welcome another opportunity to work in the Premier League.
After being pressed on links to Manchester United at the time, he said: “I’d rather not answer but it is no secret that I loved it at Chelsea, I loved it in England.
"I loved it in the Premier League for sure, it was a very, very special time and I remember it very well.”

It had seemed for a while that Tuchel and Bayern would renege on their agreement to part ways in the summer and both parties held talks over potentially extending their arrangement. Those talks failed to come to fruition, though, and former Manchester City captain Vincent Kompany was poached from Burnley to become the German giants' new head coach.

headline: 'I knew Roy Keane before he joined Man Utd – I noticed huge change in him after he moved'
body: Former Tottenham and Manchester United ace Teddy Sheringham explained the change Roy Keane underwent after his move to Old Trafford and how his game morphed for the better
Teddy Sheringham played with Roy Keane at Nottingham Forest and noticed a massive change in the Irishman after his Manchester United move.

Midfield brute-turned pundit Keane arrived at Old Trafford in 1993 for a then- British transfer record of £3.75million after spending three years in the east Midlands, and enjoyed a vastly successful 12 years with the Red Devils - winning the Premier League seven times and a Champions League to boot.

The pair of Keane and Sheringham reunited in Manchester four years later under Sir Alex Ferguson, where the Englishman added to an already eye-wateringly talented side featuring David Beckham, Paul Scholes and Andy Cole.
However, Sheringham saw a change in Keane when the two took the pitch in a different shade of red for the first time, as the once attack-minded midfielder had been crafted into a defensive general.
"I knew Roy from my time at Nottingham Forest, before we became team-mates at Man United later on down the line," Sheringham began, speaking at the launch of Ladbrokes' Gaffer of all Accas.

"There was definitely a change in him as a player, without a doubt. When I was at Forest, he'd only just broken into the first-team when I arrived there, and he was an absolutely phenomenal, up and down, central midfielder. I played up-front with Cloughie [Nigel Clough] and so there wasn't a lot of pace up there at all. So, every time the ball came up to me or Nigel, he'd be running beyond us.

"He was such a different player, by the time I got to Man United. He was a sitting midfielder who controlled the game, he didn't go forward half as much as what he used to. Whether he was told to do that, or whether his game had just changed, I don't know.

"But at Forest, every time the ball came up to me, he'd be running beyond me, whereas at United, that just didn't happen. Fergie [Sir Alex Ferguson] had probably had a chat with him, or maybe he'd worked his own game out himself, and he just thought he'd end up running himself into the ground if he didn't change his game. But he was a phenomenal youngster, and changed his game perfectly."

Keane retired in 2006 after a brief spell with Celtic, during which he won a league and cup double. Shortly after hanging up his boots, he took up a managerial role at Sunderland and guided them to promotion in his first year in charge. He moved to manage Ipswich Town in 2009 before assistant spells - his latest role with former club Forest in 2019.

Having turned most of his attention to punditry, appearing on Sky Sports and ITV, Keane looks to have put coaching behind him. Sheringham hopes there may be at least one more coaching job left in him, although he isn't confident of seeing it materialise.

"I do think there's another job out there in management for Roy Keane," Sheringham continued. "I'd have actually liked to have seen him in charge at Man United at some stage; I think he just has that aura about him. I don't think you're going to get him out of the position he's in now, though; I think he's found a lovely little niche for himself, what he's doing with Gary Neville and Jamie Carragher.

"I'd be very surprised if he went into management now, especially with his track record of reacting to things when they're not going his way, as a manager. He could very easily be in a job and out of it again in six months, and find himself with nothing. I'd have loved to have seen him in charge of Man United, but I don't think that's going to happen now."

headline: Bruno Fernandes makes feelings clear on Cristiano Ronaldo playing at 2026 World Cup
body: Portugal legend Cristiano Ronaldo scored his 131st international goal and the 900th of his professional career on Thursday night, at a time when his place in the Portugal lineup has been questioned
Bruno Fernandes insists Cristiano Ronaldo can shine at the 2026 World Cup - if he wants to.

The Portugal captain scored the 900th goal of his legendary career in Thursday night, as his side beat Croatia 2-1 in their UEFA Nations League clash. It was his 131st goal for his country, but came on the back of a disappointing Euro 2024, where he struggled.
Questions have been asked as to whether the Saudi-based striker, who will be 41 when the World Cup rolls around in two years time, will still have what it takes to be part of the Seleccao squad.
But Ronaldo has not given up hope of playing and Manchester United skipper Fernandes insists it will be ultimately be up to him.
“It’s his decision and it depends on whether he feels good and at a high level,” said Portugal team-mate Fernandes.

“We know that he is capable of reaching a certain age with this great level of demand, but it is up to him to decide and I am sure that he will decide in favour of his well-being and the national team.”
Former United and Real Madrid star Ronaldo was visibly overwhelmed when he converted Nuno Mendes’ cross in the 34th minute of Portugal’s win over Croatia, collapsing to the ground in tears.
“Only me, and the people around me know how difficult it is to work daily to be physically and psychologically well and reach goal 900,” said Ronaldo following his first strike since June.
“It’s a unique milestone in my career and it was with a lot of emotion I celebrated that goal. It represents a lot.

“It was the number I wanted to achieve for a long time and I knew I would achieve it because, as I continue to play, it would happen naturally. I already won two trophies for Portugal, something I really wanted. Whatever comes next is spectacular.”
Writing on social media, five-time Ballon d’Or winner Ronaldo added: “I dreamed of this and I have more dreams.”

headline: Why Thomas Tuchel turned down Man Utd amid new uncertainty over Erik ten Hag's position
body: Thomas Tuchel met with Manchester United over the possibility of taking over at Old Trafford before Erik ten Hag prolonged his stay with the club when the Red Devils triggered an extension
Thomas Tuchel rejected the opportunity to manage Manchester United due to conflicts over the club's transfer policy.

The German coach met with Sir Jim Ratcliffe to discuss the prospect of taking on the Old Trafford hotseat, while United were conducting their review and had yet to make a decision on Erik ten Hag's future. Tuchel brought his time to an end with Bayern Munich following the 2023/24 season and is now without a role.

The former Chelsea boss removed himself from contention however. While reports suggested the 51-year-old had decided to take a break from football, it appears he was not entirely happy with what was on offer with a return to the Premier League.

While United had earned FA Cup honours, an eighth place finish in the division left plenty of uncertainty around the squad. United were still waiting for their new footballing hierarchy to get to work in the shape of Omar Berrada and sporting director Dan Ashworth, with a compensation package yet to be agreed for the latter.

Bild report that Tuchel was unconvinced by the Red Devil's transfer approach. While the ex-Borussia Dortmund manager was very near taking on the job, the structure appears to have proven a dealbreaker.

German pundit Marcel Reif told the outlet: "I would have bet a lot that Tuchel would replace Ten Hag. I recently had another conversation with someone who is very close to that. It was pretty far along, almost in agreement.

"As far as the squad is concerned, the considerations were different. Tuchel said pretty much at the finish line: 'I’m not doing that! I won’t do that to myself again, that I go to a club and then things come from outside.'"

United were active in the summer transfer window under Ashworth and technical director Jason Wilcox. The club also appeared to rely on Ten Hag's input as they once again signed players he was familiar with in Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui.
The club also signed Joshua Zirkzee, Leny Yoro and Manuel Ugarte. The Dutch coach must now bed in his new additions but has faced a difficult start to the season and renewed scrutiny of his position.
The 13-times Premier League champions won their opening day match against Fulham but have since tasted defeat against Brighton and Liverpool.

The Dutchman has looked to defend his record by highlight his success in cup competitions. "Listen, we won, the last two years, behind City, the most trophies in English football, so we performed already the last two seasons.
"That is the reality, they are the facts. And, yeah, also this year, we want to win and we want to win trophies."

headline: Roy Keane says one Man Utd player is 'entitled' to have a quiet game
body: Bruno Fernandes failed to make much of an impact during Manchester United's 3-0 defeat to Liverpool last week, but Roy Keane reckons the Portugal international has earned a let off
Roy Keane has leapt to the defence of Bruno Fernandes after his poor performance against Liverpool.

Manchester United have made an awful start to the new campaign, having lost two of their opening three Premier League matches. A 3-0 hammering at the hands of rivals Liverpool left a sour taste in the mouth heading into the international break, and Keane says he wasn't happy with how many mistakes his former side made during the game.

Speaking about the game on the latest episode of the Stick to Football podcast, the former Red Devils skipper, 53, questioned United's tactical incoherence while accusing key players of failing to "turn up". "Bruno never turned up - [but] Bruno's entitled to have a quiet game," the Irishman said.

Earlier, Jamie Carragher had criticised United's sloppiness on the ball, which as a result made them a little unstable in midfield. In response, Keane insisted that it was the defenders' jobs to provide stability, and that if errors are made by the midfielders, the players behind them should be stepping in to put the fire out.

"When you make mistakes you hope your defenders cover you, or your goalkeeper," he said. "United are not really a settled team because there are still players coming to the club, and that's not an excuse, [but] when you're not at it you make mistakes."

Gary Neville then asked Keane whether he thought United needed to get better at playing the ball out from the back, or whether it was worth ditching the philosophy. "A little bit of both," he replied. "You're not expecting United to go long, but with United there's still an element of [mimics a player hesitating and grimacing on the ball], they don't look as if there's a flow to them."

United's playing style has been heavily scrutinised in recent months, with critics often slamming Ten Hag for failing to establish a discernible system for his team. Performances were poor throughout last season, and although blushes were partially spared by a surprise FA Cup final triumph over Manchester City in May, the campaign has gone down as one of the most disappointing in the club's history.

After picking up just three points from a possible nine so far, United's 2024/25 season is threatening to go the way of the preceding campaign. Up next for Ten Hag's men is a trip to Southampton before an EFL Cup clash with League One club Barnsley, with both games arguably in the must-win bracket.

Fernandes, meanwhile, has been something of a shining light in an otherwise gloomy period for the Manchester club. The 29-year-old has scored 79 goals in 237 matches and has been crowned the club's Player of the Year award three times in five-and-a-half seasons. His form in big games has, however, come under scrutiny in the past.

headline: Steve McClaren leaves fans in stitches after being encouraged to try Jamaican dialect
body: If Steve McClaren has started as he means to go on as Jamaica manager, it's already clear fans have a very entertaining chapter in the football icon's tale awaiting them
All it took was one training session for Steve McClaren to yield precisely what fans wanted of him as Jamaica manager.

The Yorkshireman has taken over the Reggae Boyz in what promises to be one of the more peculiar portions of an illustrious football career. But his time in the Caribbean is already proving to be the gift we hope never stops giving. The same man who gave football one of its most memorable memes while in charge of Dutch club FC Twente is back at it again. And this time, he's speaking Patois.

That's after the Jamaican FA published footage from the aftermath of ex-England manager McClaren's first training session in charge of the team. There, he can be seen engaging in an awkward half-thumb-up, half-fist-bump in an interview with the Reggae Boyz YouTube channel, who encouraged him to try Patois.

"You said something else this morning? No, something else," said the ex-Manchester United assistant with a pained expression across his face, struggling to recall the piece of slang. "It was something. . ."

The unknown individual thought he was referring to the phrases "big up" or "full active." But only when McClaren hears the greeting "seal it up" - which is sealed with a flick of each other's thumbs - does he jump into life.
"That's what he said!" exclaimed McClaren in delight at his discovery. "Look me in the eye. . .seal it up."

The cap-touting coach appeared lost but then was found thanks to a little help from his new colleague. And online spectators couldn't get enough of the crossover fans never knew they needed all this time.

"Was like he’s lived there all his life," wrote one admirer in response to the video. Others couldn't help but lap up McClaren throwing himself into the job, with another lauding: "Yes Steve, seal it up!!

"He's like a chameleon, blends into any environment," said another sarcastic viewer, this time linking footage of McClaren's infamous Dutch accent while coaching in the Eredivisie. Thankfully, the 63-year-old is yet to throw himself quite so committedly into the role while managing Jamaica - but there's still time.
Having only taken his first training session with the team on Tuesday, McClaren will soon be baptised in the role when the Reggae Boyz host Cuba in a CONCACAF Nations League clash on Friday.

Speaking after his much-anticipated arrival at the helm, McClaren said: "From the first day [of the training camp] the players came in, it's been great energy and spirit amongst them. They've shown that on the training field.

"We can control the controllable, which we've tried to do. We just have keep things simple. I'm going to concentrate on the performance - if we get the performance from the players, normally you get the win."
Performances will ultimately dictate just how long McClaren lasts after taking his first senior management role since 2019. However, it already appears as though vibes are a guarantee.

headline: Former Man Utd academy coach reveals why Angel Gomes was destined for the top
body: Angel Gomes has been handed a first England call-up, with those who watched him go through the ranks at Man Utd not surprised he has made it to the full squad
For those who watched Angel Gomes progress through the youth ranks at Manchester United, he was always destined to reach the top.
He may have been slight in stature and build, but his natural talent, allied to a steely focus, marked him out as a youngster who had the ability to play at the highest level.
Gomes may have been forced to leave his boyhood club United in 2020 when his contract expired, but his talent and work ethic have led to a deserved first full England call-up.
Having played for every England age group since Under-16s – and captained the Three Lions to victory in the Under-17 World Cup in 2017 – the call-up is vindication for his relentless graft.
Now a regular starter at Lille, Gomes has emerged as a midfielder of stature, his progress having alerted a host of Europe's top clubs, with his contract expiring at the end of this season.
The fact he is in demand is no surprise to Paul McGuinness, former academy manager and Under-18s coach at United, who watched Gomes progress since he arrived at the club aged just six.
In nearly a quarter of a century at United, McGuinness helped oversee the development of more than 90 players who went on to play in the first-team, 23 of which became full internationals.
With Gomes set to earn his first England cap, that figure is set to rise to 24, with McGuinness claiming the call-up is a reward for the 24-year-old's dedication to maximising his talent.
“He stood out when he was in the academy because he was smaller than everybody else,” said McGuinness, son of former United player and manager, Wilf.
“But he was brilliant technically on the ball and had a real love for football. He had a huge natural talent and what we did was always encourage those skilful talents.

“One of our mottos was 'skill is king', so Angel was always in a place where he was going to thrive and we were playing the type of football that would suit him. It's a great testament to him, his coaches at United right through to his coaches with England, that someone who was so small has been recognised repeatedly.

“He represented every age group with England, captained the team that won the Under-17 World Cup and has performed well for the Under-21s. That's why Lee Carsley has brought him into the full squad and the benefit of having stability in your coaching set-up and system - people see these young players over the years.

“But if you get a new manager in, like they've had at United quite a few times, they don't know them as well. But with England, they've seen Angel all the way through and trusted his talent. Lee has seen him close-up in a tournament for the Under-21s, for four or five weeks, so in that sense he must have great belief in him.

“That's a plus of having someone who's been through the system [as England boss]. If you'd just plucked some top manager from out there, he would never have picked Angel, because he wouldn't have a clue. So to have that continuity – in terms of managers and coaches – in the international system is a real strength.”

Gomes was handed his United debut in May 2017 by Jose Mourinho. At 16 years and 263 days old, he was the youngest player to make his United debut since Busby Babe Duncan Edwards in 1953. McGuinness added: “Angel has always had great belief in his ability. He had no problem moving up age groups. He'd be 12 or 13, playing against the Under-18s and he just got better and better.”

headline: Zinedine Zidane hint on replacing Erik ten Hag at Man Utd after training ground visit
body: Zinedine Zidane has not been in management since leaving Real Madrid in May 2021, but he has once again been linked to Manchester United, with Erik ten Hag under pressure
Zinedine Zidane has admitted he is open to a long-awaited return to management after speculation linking him to Manchester United resurfaced.

Zidane has been without a job since leaving Real Madrid for the second time in May 2021. The 52-year-old Frenchman has been linked with several roles in the past three years, including United, Bayern Munich and the national team jobs at United States, Brazil and Algeria, but is still biding his time.

He sparked rumours that he could be preparing for a return to the dugout this week when he was spotted attending a training session at Real Betis. It comes amid pressure on Erik ten Hag at United following a poor start to the season, just months after the club’s new leadership team openly courted other managers.

Thomas Tuchel, Graham Potter and Gareth Southgate were among those considered by Sir Jim Ratcliffe and his advisors, while L’Equipe stated that Zidane was also interested in taking over from Ten Hag. In the end, Ten Hag was given a stay of execution, but the Dutchman remains on shaky ground after the 3-0 thrashing by Liverpool at Old Trafford.

At the premiere of a film about his former Juventus manager Marcelo Lippi in February, Zidane was asked if he would return to coaching. He replied: "Why not, anything can happen. Now I’m doing other things, but we'll see. I'd certainly like to return to the bench."

Zidane has only ever managed at Real Madrid so far in his coaching career, but was incredibly successful over his two spells at the club. The former midfielder won two La Liga titles and three Champions League titles before walking away at the end of the 2020/21 campaign.

He has taken an unusually long time out since then, but his ethos is clear: he will only return for the right opportunity. "Never say never," Zidane told L’Equipe in 2022. "Especially when you are a coach today. If I go back to a club, it is to win. I say this with all modesty. That's why I can't just go anywhere.
"For other reasons, too. Certain conditions make things more difficult. When someone says to me, 'Do you want to go to Manchester [United]?' I understand English but I don't fully master it.

"I know there are coaches who go to clubs without speaking the language, but I work differently. To win, many elements come into play. It's a global context. I know what I need to win. Of course, I might not always win, but I know that you need to have this, this and this. And I want to do everything on my side to optimise my chances of victory."

headline: Jadon Sancho ripped to shreds by ex-Chelsea star over his motivation for transfer from Man Utd
body: Jadon Sancho left Manchester United on loan for the second time this year to join Chelsea on Transfer Deadline Day, and former Blues midfielder Emmanuel Petit has been left baffled by the decision
Emmanuel Petit is completely confused by Jadon Sancho's decision to join Chelsea on Deadline Day and questioned the player's motivation.

Sancho left Manchester United on loan for the second time after growing frustrated with Erik ten Hag. After a stint back at Borussia Dortmund in the second half of last season, he opted for a return to his native London.

However, ex-Chelsea midfielder Petit is baffled as to why Sancho would choose to join an already packed Blues squad, given the intense competition for places. The Frenchman even joked about the lack of space in Chelsea's dressing room after their busy summer influx.

"When I saw they had signed Jadon Sancho on Deadline Day, I wondered if there was even any shirt numbers left for him," he told sports betting site BetVictor (via football.london). "Imagine him opening the door to the dressing room and seeing so many players they don't all fit in the same dressing room! At the training ground they must have two dressing rooms, three pitches and 12 physios.

“The club are not the only ones responsible for the situation. It also comes down to the players. How can Sancho bring himself to sign for Chelsea after what happened at Manchester United? He was loaned to Borussia Dortmund, then went back to United, and now he’s off to Chelsea who have 40 or so players and he is just one of them."

The former France international didn't hold back in slamming the move, arguing it could be a money-driven decision for Sancho, who is set to struggle for guaranteed playing time once again. Petit continued: "Hasn't he had enough of moving around clubs, losing his way on the pitch and losing his confidence? Now he's at a club that has no consistency, lacking in confidence and results. If he's not there for the money, what is he there for?"

This isn't the first time voices have been raised concerning Chelsea's controversial transfer market strategy. The dazzling summer spree overseen by Enzo Maresca has looked hectic, marked by the arrival of 11 new first-team players setting up shop in Stamford Bridge.

Before Sancho entered the scene, the Blues had already thrown £100million at the acquisitions of Pedro Neto and Joao Felix. That's taking into account the club had an already robust wing selection, including talents like Cole Palmer, Christopher Nkunku, Mykhailo Mudryk, Noni Madueke and Carney Chukwuemeka.

The new football season is upon us and with 500 live games to watch, as well access to Cricket, Golf, F1, Boxing, NFL and the NBA across eight dedicated channels, Sky Sports is the only way to watch all the action.

"I'd probably say Frank Lampard," the winger told talkSPORT in 2021 when asked to name his England idol. "I was a Chelsea fan growing up, I can't lie! Didier Drogba and Frank Lampard were my favourite players at the time.
"I just love Frank Lampard and how he played his game; he was so direct and so composed on the ball. I like things like that."

Those comments suggest the Camberwell native's affection for all things Chelsea run way deeper than Petit might expect. Sancho's next task is clear as he seeks to win over new coach Maresca, disprove critics like Petit, and show his dedication extends far beyond any financial incentives.

headline: Lisandro Martinez on Sir Alex Ferguson's Man Utd role and why he "wouldn't dare" cross him
body: Sir Alex Ferguson retired from management in 2013 but is still a regular face on matchdays at Old Trafford and Lisandro Martinez has opened up on his "connection" to the players, hailing him as "the God of Manchester"

Man United defender Lisandro Martinez has revealed his admiration for Sir Alex Ferguson and says the the club's new owners have ensured the legendary boss remains an influential voice who continues to give support to the players, even if he "wouldn't dare" to bother the Scot too much.

Sir Alex is the most successful manager in United's history after winning 38 trophies, including 13 Premier League titles and two Champions League trophies after an incredible spell spanning 26 years.

The 82-year-old retired from management in 2013 but is still a regular face on matchdays at Old Trafford as a guest of new chief Sir Jim Ratcliffe - and Martinez has opened up on his "connection" to the players, hailing him as "the God of Manchester" as he reflected on his meetings with the Scot.

"I have met Ferguson three or four times. Ferguson is the God of Manchester," he told Argentinian outlet La Nacion. "He is a person who gave a lot to the club and who continues to give because he remains connected. Now, the new owners have also included him."

Martinez explained how Ferguson reached out to him after Argentina won the 2022 World Cup in Qatar to congratulate him on the achievement and said they had also spoken after United won the Carabao Cup and FA Cup in the last year. He added that he was eager not to "invade his space" by speaking to him too much.

"When [Argentina] won the World Cup we spoke a little, he congratulated me. Later, also when we won the Carabao and the FA Cup – he is a legend of world football and I respect people’s privacy. Of course I would like to be able to talk to him, actually listen to him, but I would not dare to invade his space."
Martinez joined United in 2022 and has gone on to feature 63 times - though the centre-back has struggled at times with injury problems.

He opened up on his fitness woes in the same interview, admitting he was "filled with fear and mistrust" after picking up a handful of issues, including a foot and knee injury that kept him out for long spells of last season.

"It is hard to repeatedly go through injuries, because injuries destroy your head, they fill you with fear, with mistrust," he added. "Emotionally everything is negative after the injuries: you become insecure, you stop believing in yourself, you don’t even walk well, you don’t know what will happen to you.

"The injuries have improved me a lot, they made me a better person and a better player, a better professional. Precisely, after everything I went through, today I feel very calm, very emotionally balanced. I felt that it was a goal that at some point I had to accomplish."

Martinez has featured in all three of United's games this season but has been part of a side that has come under pressure following back to back defeats under Erik ten Hag. He played the full 90 minutes in United's 3-0 defeat at home to Liverpool last time out before heading on his international break.
His Argentina team beat Chile 3-0 in a World Cup qualifier on Thursday and face another against Colombia on Tuesday before the defender returns for a trip to Southampton on September 14.

headline: Jurgen Klopp weighs in on Jadon Sancho's Man Utd exit with "he's useless" criticism
body: Manchester United chose to let Jadon Sancho leave on deadline day with his Chelsea loan set to become permanent - but Jurgen Klopp had criticised their treatment of the player
Jurgen Klopp was not a fan of Manchester United 's decision to offload Jadon Sancho - insisting the manager has to stick by the player and not just deem him "useless".

The winger's future had been the subject of debate heading into this summer after he managed to regain his form whilst at on loan at Borussia Dortmund last term, helping them to reach the Champions League final.

That came after his public spat with Erik ten Hag - with the player criticising the manager after he was left out of a matchday squad 12 months ago. That saw him left out in the cold in Manchester, before he was reintegrated back into the first-team group this summer.

A deadline day switch to Chelsea, though, looks to have ended his time at Old Trafford. The £72million asset has headed to west London on loan with the Blues having an obligation to buy Sancho. All of which means his underwhelming stint in Manchester is over - but Klopp believes he should've been shown far more support before he was sold.

The ex-Liverpool boss said prior to his deadline day switch: "If the whole world loses trust and faith in the player, the manager has to be the one behind the player. I cannot just buy into that ‘he's useless,’ like other clubs did by the way - buying a player for £80 million and then sending him out on loan!"

Sancho leaves the Red Devils having scored just 12 times. The Englishman has also lost his spot with the Three Lions since moving back to the Premier League but is now seeking to prove himself in the top flight at Chelsea, albeit they have huge competition for places.

United's sporting director Dan Ashworth claimed it was the depth in their attack which meant they green lighted Sancho's exit. The club have numerous options and Ten Hag had overlooked Sancho for both matchday squads this season - highlighting the limited game time he was set to get.

Ashworth told Sky Sports : "I think with any player, whether it’s Jadon, whether it’s Scott [McTominay] or whether it’s Aaron [Wan-Bissaka], if there’s a preference that they would like to move and go to a new club and it’s right for them and it’s right for us, then you have to explore it.

"We felt we had enough depth in that particular position to be able to cover it, we’ve got four really good wide players, Jadon was a fifth, and it just enabled us to make that decision. If it was good for him and good for us it was something we were willing to consider."

headline: Man Utd transfer news: Casemiro 'shortlisted' as Erik ten Hag signing's exit stance clear
body: Manchester United's summer transfer business might not be completely finished, with clubs from a select number of leagues still able to make new signings in September
Despite losing two of their first three Premier League matches, Manchester United have reasons to be optimistic about their summer transfer business.

Manuel Ugarte joined from Paris Saint-Germain on deadline day, joining Sekou Kone in completing a late switch. The late double swoop followed earlier moves for Joshua Zirzkee, Leny Yoro, Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui.

United also offloaded plenty of players, some for fees and others when their contracts expired. Raphael Varane and Anthony Martial were in the latter camp, with Donny van de Beek and Aaron Wan-Bissaka among those in the former.

There might be more business to take care of before the window shuts for teams in other leagues, though. That's one of the areas in focus as Mirror Football brings you the latest from around Old Trafford.

Clubs in the Turkish Super Lig have until September 13 to make final additions to their squads, prompting links with out-of-favour Premier League stars. One such player is United midfielder Casemiro, who endured a tough time against Liverpool in the last league game.

The Brazilian has dropped further down the pecking order following Ugarte's August arrival, and United could end up cutting their losses on the £60m signing from Real Madrid. Galatasaray are thought to be keen, with The Times indicating he remains on their radar.

Galatasaray have cleared space in their squad, with Portugal international Sergio Oliveira leaving for Olympiacos. However, United's decision to include Casemiro in their Europa League squad suggests an exit might not be entirely straighforward.
Antony is another United star attracting interest from Turkey. However, despite reported efforts from Jose Mourinho's Fenerbahce, the winger is thought to have no plans to leave Old Trafford.

“I see reports about a potential exit on loan. Antony’s plan is clear: Manchester United," the former Ajax star's agent Junior Pedroso said earlier this year. "He wants to stay, he’s only focused on Man United. We already spoke about that with the club.”

Mirror Football understands Antony wants to stay at United and prove himself, despite seeing opportunities limited of late. He hasn't started a competitive game for his club since the 4-0 defeat at Crystal Palace in early May, and has played just one minute of football this season.

Matthijs de Ligt has outlined the role played by Erik ten Hag in convincing him to join Manchester United. The Dutch defender has been reunited with his former Ajax boss after joining United from Bayern Munich, and made his first Premier League start in Sunday's defeat against Liverpool.

"Yeah obviously [he was] a really important part because he knows me really well, I know him really well," De Ligt told club media. "He made me captain also at Ajax. Also at my time at Ajax he gave me a lot of confidence, he gave me a lot of motivation to try to lead the team."

De Ligt will return to club duties after joining up with the Netherlands squad for the September international break. Ronald Koeman's side have a UEFA Nations League double-header, playing Bosnia and Herzegovina and Germany.

headline: Liverpool tunnel cam captures Trent Alexander-Arnold's telling reaction to Old Trafford
body: Liverpool fans reckon Trent Alexander-Arnold was highly confident of beating Manchester United after spotting his facial expression when getting off the team bus at Old Trafford
Trent Alexander-Arnold could be seen grinning from ear to ear as he entered Old Trafford before Liverpool's 3-0 demolition of Manchester United.
Arne Slot's side were a class above their rivals down the M62 last Sunday. Alexander-Arnold had a goal ruled out before a Luis Diaz brace put them two to the good before half-time.
Both of those goals came about after Casemiro had lost possession in his own half, with Erik ten Hag hauling him off at the break. But it was more of the same after the restart.

Kobbie Mainoo was dispossessed before Salah, who'd set up Diaz's efforts, was slipped in by Dominik Szoboszlai to finish first time past Andre Onana. There could've been more for the visitors, who saw out the game comfortably thereafter.

And Liverpool fans reckon Alexander-Arnold was assured they'd be leaving with three points well before kick-off after seeing him getting off the team bus upon their arrival. As seen on the club's YouTube channel, the right-back was booed by the United fans who were watching on from behind a barrier.
In response, he simply beamed back at them as he swaggered into the ground. Taking to the comments, one viewer argued: "Trent knows we're going to win when he gets off from the bus."

"Trent already laughing from the entrance... knowing they gonna cook United," echoed a second, with a third joking: "That Trent smile when they booed him while he was entering.... he knew what kind of spanking was coming."

A fourth reacted: "Trent's smile while getting booed walking from the bus. He knew what was coming." And a fifth wrote: "Love the way Trent was laughing at their fans on the way in Old Trafford and on the way out."

Alexander-Arnold was also seen giving some back to the Red Devils faithful when departing Old Trafford post-match. Just like he'd done on the pitch to the away end after full-time, he held up three fingers to remind them of the scoreline.

He wasn't wholly happy, though, having been substituted in the second half for the third time out of three under Slot. His frustration was clear to see as he made his way off the pitch for Conor Bradley with a little under 15 minutes to play, with his contract notably expiring next summer.

headline: Cristiano Ronaldo told he can 'become next Man Utd manager' when he retires
body: Cristiano Ronaldo is in the latter stages of his career and former Manchester United and Liverpool striker Michael Owen can see a path into management for the Portugal superstar
Cristiano Ronaldo has been tipped to head into management when he retires.

The five-times Ballon d'Or winner has scored scored 900 goals in 1,238 matches but still has aspirations of extending his career. The 39-year-old has his heart set on securing 1,000 goals, and could yet extend his contract, due to expire in 2025, with Saudi Pro League side Al-Nassr.

The Portuguese international has already expanded his avenues as time winds down on his career. Ronaldo has recently launched a YouTube channel and has ambitions of surpassing Mr Beast in subscribers.

The forward expects to retire in two or three years when he brings his stint with Al-Nassr to a close. Former Liverpool and Real Madrid striker Michael Owen believes that after what he saw on the sidelines during Euro 2024, management could follow.
Ronaldo was an active presence by the dugout, when he was not on the field in Germany. Owen suggests it hinted at his ambition.

“Just looking from the outside, it feels like he might want to be at the side of the pitch managing Portugal like he did at Euro 2016," he said per Goal. “He looks like a coach, he looks like he wants to coach, so he might want to go down that route. The Portugal job, probably in the future, we might have his name on it, you never know.
"Of course, if he does well, then great teams like Manchester United, Real Madrid would then be looking at him."

Owen acknowledged, given Ronaldo's profile, that club ownership could be more likely for the superstar. The ex-England international sees a path where Ronaldo and long-term rival Lionel Messi could both swap the pitch for an owner's box.

"I’d be fascinated to see what Cristiano Ronaldo is going to do when he retires," he said. “Obviously, they’re [Messi and Ronaldo] not far away from that being the case. Their life has been in football and they absolutely love the sport and whether they can walk away from it in its entirety remains to be seen, they might want to go and own a club.
“They’re probably one of a few footballers that have got the money to go and own a big club so that could take precedence over coaching.

headline: Manchester United left with fresh Casemiro dilemma after 'call it a day' demand
body: Manchester United midfielder Casemiro may have left the club in a tricky position with his determination to remain at Old Trafford despite transfer interest arriving from elsewhere
Manchester United face a dilemma with midfielder Casemiro determined to remain at the club this season.

The Premier League's transfer window has been shut for almost a week, while the possibility of a move to the Saudi Pro League has also diminished. Nevertheless the possibility of a move to Turkey has been touted.

Galatasaray have been linked with completing a deal for the 32-year-old former Real Madrid star with deals to the Super Lig possible for another eight days. Okan Buruk's side have already taken advantage of their extended period available to land Victor Osimhen on loan, and have shortlisted Casemiro as they look to strengthen in midfield.

It is unlikely however, that the Turkish side could match his £375,000-per-week that sees him as United's top-earner. And the Brazilian, who has been left out of his national squad for fixtures against Ecuador and Paraguay, has little interest in leaving Old Trafford.

Instead, Casemiro is looking to return to the heights he found in his first season at the club, and being hauled off after 45 minutes against Liverpool has not inspired him to move elsewhere, per the Mail. The five-times Champions League winner was a target of criticism from Gary Neville and Jamie Carragher once again, months on from being urged to 'call it a day' by the former Liverpool defender.

United now face the prospect of their top-earner being left among the substitutes following the signing of Manuel Ugarte from Paris Saint-Germain. The Uruguay international was not eligible to face the Reds at Old Trafford having not completed his transfer in time but after making the £50million move will be expected to come into the starting XI.

Erik ten Hag has already admitted it could take months before Ugarte becomes an important player however. That could yet leave Casemiro with some opportunity to prove himself before dropping down the pecking order.

"It will take time. It's not like I'm Harry Potter. That's what you have to acknowledge," said United's boss. "If you see [new signing] Manuel Ugarte, he didn't play so far in the season. Not one match minute. So he needs to build his fitness and then we have to build him in the team and I'm sure he'll be an important player.
"But that will take a couple of weeks, maybe even months. Joshua Zirkzee, he made big steps in the last three or four weeks and I was very pleased with his performance today."

headline: Jamie Carragher and Gary Neville clash again over Liverpool and Man Utd managers
body: Manchester United kept their manager over the summer while Liverpool made a change in the dugout, prompting Gary Neville and Jamie Carragher to debate the two cubs' choices
Jamie Carragher and Gary Neville found themselves at loggerheads as they debated Manchester United and Liverpool's contrasting decisions on the managerial front.

Liverpool knew as long ago as January that they would need a new manager this summer. They ended up appointing Arne Slot, but only after links with the likes of Xabi Alonso and Ruben Amorim ended up going nowhere.

Bayer Leverkusen manager Alonso and Sporting boss Amorim both stayed put, as did United manager Erik ten Hag. A change in the dugout at Old Trafford was considered, with at least one candidate sounded out, but ultimately the club's higher-ups kept the faith.

Ten Hag and Slot faced off in the final Premier League game before the international break, with Liverpool's new man coming out on top. However, Neville and Carragher found themselves arguing over the matter of first-choice managers for the two clubs.
"I think there was some sentiment after the final. The fans wanted Ten Hag to be kept on and backed," Neville said on the Stick to Football podcast

"They have seen enough managers sacked over the years. I think they sounded out Graham Potter, Gareth Southgate, Roberto De Zerbi and Thomas Tuchel around that time. But there was a bit of a negative reaction from fans.

"There is no doubt they were having a flirt around the market and seeing what they could do. I think if there was an unbelievable manager that could improve United 100 percent, beyond what Ten Hag could, they would have made a change. Liverpool had six months to replace Jurgen Klopp and still found it challenging to get their top targets."

"Where are you getting it from that Arne Slot wasn't Liverpool's top target?" Carragher asked in response, only to be reminded by Neville of his own claims that the Merseyside club would "definitely" go after their former midfielder Alonso.

"That is my opinion!" Carragher replied. "I am sure they did ask about Alonso and were told straight away that he was staying at Bayer Leverkusen. You’re saying Liverpool had this big search…how do we know exactly what went on behind the scenes at Liverpool? Why didn’t Man United employ Arne Slot then?”

Neville suggested United would have considered Slot, who was linked with other Premier League jobs during his time at Feyenoord. “I think they’d have looked at him, but thought can we really get rid of a guy [in Ten Hag] who has won two trophies in two years, who hasn’t been backed by the proper structure, to bring another Dutch manager in?" he asked.
Carragher was having none of it, though. "What do you mean without a proper structure?!" he said. "He’s gone out and brought in everyone he wanted!"

Speaking during NOS' coverage of Euro 2024, Ten Hag confirmed United were considering Tuchel "Manchester United have told me that they spoke with Tuchel, but they eventually came to the conclusion that they already have the best manager," he said in June.

Weeks later, he agreed a contract extension with the club until 2026. “In my discussions with the club, we have found complete unity in our vision for reaching those goals, and we are all strongly committed to making that journey together," Ten Hag said when the deal was confirmed.
Since being backed, though United's manager has endured a tough start to the season with two defeats from three. Slot, in contrast, has won three games from three as a Premier League manager.

headline: Dan Ashworth continues Man Utd overhaul with crucial Old Trafford appointment
body: Manchester United part-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe has made a number of significant backroom hires since arriving at Old Trafford and there is another on the way thanks to Dan Ashworth
Manchester United's hiring spree has continued with new interim performance director Sam Erith due to start work at the club on Monday.

United part-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe has been busy behind the scenes since taking charge of football affairs during the 2023-24 season. Sporting director Dan Ashworth is among the high-profile backroom hires, and the former FA director of elite development has reportedly played a significant part in the latest hire.

Erith, who previously spent time with Premier League clubs Manchester City and Tottenham Hotspur, held a number of roles within the FA earlier in his career. Ashworth himself spent six years with English football's governing body, leaving his post in 2018.

United appointed a new CEO and techical director earlier in the summer before bringing in Ashworth when they reached an agreement with his previous club Newcastle United. Now, fresh reports suggest the 53-year-old targeted Erith for a role at the club.

According to The Mail, Erith will work closely with United's football leadership team when he joins until the end of the current season. The publication makes reference to his experience in performance, health and sports science.

Erith has updated his LinkedIn profile to make reference to starting work at United in September 2024. His most recent role has been as SVP Player Performance and Science Lead with New York Knicks owners Madison Square Garden Sports Corp.

He spent six years as Tottenham's head of sports science and more than 11 years in the same role with City, where he also had a spell as Global Lead for Human Performance. Erith also had a two-year stint with the FA in a sports science role before joining Spurs, returning to the governing body as a consultant performance coach for just over a year from March 2016.
The hire comes just days after the departure of United's deputy football director Andy O’Boyle. He had worked closely with former football director John Murtough and only joined the club in 2022.

United have endured a tough start to the season despite spending around £200m on new signings. Ashworth was asked about the on-field recruitment, but rubbished concerns about manager Erik ten Hag signing players he

"It's human nature to work with somebody you’ve worked with previously in all contexts, in all business contexts," United's sporting director said. "That is a natural sway, because you know that person, because you know that player. But we've also signed a number of players this summer who haven’t worked with Erik previously – Leny Yoro, Manuel Ugarte, he’d never worked with Joshua Zirkzee - and you can’t say 'just because he’s Dutch' that he knows him.

"You would put the whole of the English market to me [if that were the case]. He’s not worked with him before. He’s worked with Matthijs and Nous [Mazraoui] previously, but as I’ve said before, they were both on our radar and it’s a joined-up decision on who comes in and out of this football club."

headline: Why Kobbie Mainoo and Alejandro Garnacho are NOT named in Man Utd's Europa League squad
body: Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag has selected the players he will have at his disposal for what he hopes is just the first half of their Europa League campaign this season
Manchester United have submitted their 25-man squad for the upcoming Europa League campaign.

Erik ten Hag’s side are back in Europe’s secondary competition, courtesy of their FA Cup final victory over Manchester City in May. United begin their tournament at the end of September and do so as one of the favourites to lift the trophy.

That’s despite a start to the Premier League season which has seen them lose two of their opening three games, including a demolition last time out by Liverpool. But Ten Hag has reserved his best moments in the Old Trafford dugout for cup competitions, lifting two domestic trophies in as many seasons.

It hasn’t been nearly as impressive in European competitions, losing out in the quarter-finals of the 22/23 Europa League to Sevilla, before crashing out of last season’s Champions League in the groups.

They will be hoping for a significantly better crack this time around, in what is the first season of the new ‘Swiss model’ competition. United are guaranteed to play at least eight fixtures - four at home and four away - before potentially reaching the knockout stages.
Those matches will run from September 25 against Ten Hag’s old side FC Twente, right up until January 30 when they travel to FCSB in Romania.

With that in mind, Ten Hag has needed to keep one eye on the next few months when picking the group of players he will have at his disposal. Two notable omissions from the list itself are Kobbie Mainoo and Alejandro Garnacho.

The two are both integral members of Ten Hag’s squad having come through the club’s fabled academy. However, that is purely for an administrative reason, with the pair still expected to play a major role.
UEFA rules stipulate that the 25-man squad can be supplemented by a ‘B’ list of academy players, which is for club-trained players who have been with their current team for at least two years.

"A player may be registered on List B if he is born on or after 1 January 2003 and has, since his 15th birthday, been eligible to play for the club concerned for any uninterrupted period of two years, or a total of three consecutive years with a maximum of one loan period to a club from the same association for a period not longer than one year," UEFA's rules read.
"Players aged 16 may be registered on List B if they have been registered with the participating club for the previous two years without interruption."
That B list also includes the likes of Toby Collyer - who came on at half time against Liverpool - and Ethan Wheatley who was an unused substitute at Old Trafford.
Harry Amass, 17, is named on the main list, having joined from Watford's academy in 2023.

It's a very different story to Chelsea, with Enzo Maresca leaving out a host of their expensively acquired stars - including Cole Palmer - for their Europa Conference League campaign. That decision is understood to have been made with 'load management' in mind, ahead of a hectic fixture schedule.

In contrast, all of United’s summer signings are listed, including Leny Yoro, who is yet to make his competitive debut after suffering an injury in pre-season. Tyrell Malacia is involved as he continues his recovery from injury, as is Luke Shaw, currently out with a calf injury.

Manchester United Europa League squad in full: Andre Onana, Altay Bayindir, Tom Heaton, Dermot Mee; Harry Amass, Diogo Dalot, Matthijs De Ligt, Jonny Evans, Victor Lindelof, Harry Maguire, Tyrell Malacia, Lisandro Martinez, Noussair Mazraoui, Luke Shaw, Leny Yoro; Casemiro, Christian Eriksen, Bruno Fernandes, Mason Mount, Manuel Ugarte; Amad, Antony, Rasmus Hojlund, Marcus Rashford, Joshua Zirkzee.

headline: Man Utd include two forgotten Erik ten Hag signings in Europe squad as Casemiro call made
body: Manchester United begin their Europa League campaign later this month, with Red Devils boss Erik ten Hag naming the players that will be available to him during the group stage
Manchester United have included Casemiro in their squad for the upcoming Europa League campaign despite the midfielder being linked with a move away.

Casemiro's future had been up in the air since United completed their deadline day move for Manuel Ugarte, with links to the Turkish Super Lig emerging. Clubs in Turkey have until September 13 to make new signings, less than a fortnight before United begin their Europa League campaign against Erik ten Hag's former club Twente.

Ten Hag has also included Christian Eriksen in the squad after the Dane was linked with a move away. Eriksen's agent confirmed the midfielder had turned down offers from outside Europe and will stay put for now.

United's manager has also given spots to two players signed during his tenure who have been out of the first-team picture. Tyrell Malacia is available in Europe after missing last season through injury, while young left-back Harry Amass is also in the squad after joining from Watford in 2023.

All of United's big-name senior summer signings are included. That means Leny Yoro will be available to play a part in the competition once he recovers from the foot injury which kept him out of the start of the Premier League season.

United have named a 25-man squad for the competition, which can be supplemented by a 'B' list of academy players including the likes of recent debutant Toby Collyer. However, Amass - who came through Watford's academy - needed to be registered in the main squad.

"A player may be registered on List B if he is born on or after 1 January 2003 and has, since his 15th birthday, been eligible to play for the club concerned for any uninterrupted period of two years, or a total of three consecutive years with a maximum of one loan period to a club from the same association for a period not longer than one year," UEFA's rules read.
"Players aged 16 may be registered on List B if they have been registered with the participating club for the previous two years without interruption."

United reached the quarter-finals of the Europa League in Ten Hag's first season in charge, falling to eventual champions Sevilla. They took part in the Champions League last season, finishing bottom of a group which also contained Bayern Munich, FC Copenhagen and Galatasaray.

This season is the first in which the Europa League has used its new 'Swiss-style' format, with a league phase replacing the group stage. United have home matches against Twente, PAOK, Bodo/Glimt and Rangers, as well as away trips to face Porto, Fenerbahce, Viktoria Plzen and FCSB.

Manchester United Europa League squad in full: Andre Onana, Altay Bayindir, Tom Heaton, Dermot Mee; Harry Amass, Diogo Dalot, Matthijs De Ligt, Jonny Evans, Victor Lindelof, Harry Maguire, Tyrell Malacia, Lisandro Martinez, Noussair Mazraoui, Luke Shaw, Leny Yoro; Casemiro, Christian Eriksen, Bruno Fernandes, Mason Mount, Manuel Ugarte; Amad, Antony, Rasmus Hojlund, Marcus Rashford, Joshua Zirkzee.

headline: Cristiano Ronaldo and Sir Alex Ferguson’s £400 Man Utd bet – 'I need to go to the bank'
body: Former Manchester United boss Sir Alex Ferguson faced the prospect of having to delve into his own wallet to pay off star winger Cristiano Ronaldo in a light-hearted bet that got a little serious
Cristiano Ronaldo once cost Sir Alex Ferguson £400 after the Manchester United boss bet the then-young winger that he wouldn't score 15 goals over one season.

In the 2005/06 Premier League season, Ronaldo had managed to score nine goals in 33 appearances, and also notched up seven assists across the campaign. However, legendary tactician Sir Alex put across a challenge that the Portuguese wonderkid couldn't refuse – score 15 and win £400.
By December 2006, a 21-year-old Ronaldo had already scored 13 goals – including three successive braces against Aston Villa, Wigan and Reading.

After his brace against Villa, Ronaldo told reporters that his main ambition in the league this season was to score more and "beat" Ferguson. He revealed: "To beat the manager is my ambition and I want to carry on. I want to score more goals."

A goal and assist followed in United's game against Watford that they won 4-0. Then, he reached the all-important 15-goal mark with another 4-0 win over Tottenham Hotspur, scoring from the spot to secure his £400 payday.
Speaking to Sky Sports interviewer Geoff Shreeves after the match, Ferguson jokingly said: "Penalties don't count. Oh well, I'll need to go the bank."
The legendary Scotsman went on to praise Ronaldo's tenacity to be involved in every phase of the game, his natural skill and goalscoring ability that landed him a nice little three-figure sum.

"It's fantastic, the boy has come on great, he's got the courage to want the ball," Ferguson said at the time, although he made sure to share some criticism to help keep Ronaldo grounded. "I thought he played in the early parts of the match he was careless but once he got more of the ball and I think he improved because he had more of the ball.

"I think he's that type of player where you have to service him and get the ball to him and get him working in the game. He's not the player who plays in the fringes, he's a player who has to be involved all the time."

Ronaldo went on to score 23 goals in 53 appearances for United in that season, assisting 14 times and winning the 2006/07 Premier League title with the Red Devils by a six-point margin over second-placed Chelsea.

With his 17 goals in the Premier League, Ronaldo was third in the overall top goalscorer record for the season, with Didier Drogba taking home the Golden Boot with 20 goals. Blackburn Rovers' Benni McCarthy was second with 18 goals, and Wayne Rooney tied for fourth with Charlton Athletic's Mark Viduka on 14 goals.
United have unveiled their new adidas home kit with new front-of-shirt sponsors for the 2024/25 season - and you can get your hands on it right now.
Ronaldo's goalscoring only improved from then on, with the Portuguese star scoring a whopping 42 goals in all competitions for United in the 2007/08 season in just 49 appearances.

He then left United just one season later to join Real Madrid, scoring an incredible 450 goals in nine seasons for the La Liga outfit. The Portuguese icon's total goal tally comes to an unbelievable 763 goals in 1,017 professional appearances, including 240 assists.
With Ronaldo now playing his competitive football out in Saudi Arabia for Al Nassr, the 39-year-old doesn't show any signs of retiring from the sport any time soon.

headline: 'Astronomical' - how Manchester United beat Man City and Chelsea to sign Casemiro replacement
body: There is currently a buzz within Manchester United about youngster Toby Collyer.
The casual observer might think Collyer didn't pull up trees in academy games, but he's been considered a leading prospect at Carrington since he signed from Brighton in 2022.
A source said this summer that Erik ten Hag 'really likes' Collyer and another source said he records 'freakish' running stats in training that are only bettered by Bruno Fernandes.

Collyer has gone under the radar in the last two years but that's beginning to change. The midfielder made his Premier League debut in dramatic circumstances last weekend when replacing Casemiro at half-time and there should be more top-flight appearances to come.

Liverpool hammered United 3-0 and Collyer won't look back on his league debut with fondness, but he won three tackles, made three recoveries, won seven duels and completed all of his attempted dribbles, which meant he could be happy with his individual performance.

Collyer enjoyed a promising summer and there have been signs along the way that he can earn a prominent first-team role. He was named as a substitute eight times last season and Ten Hag was spotted in conversation with the 20-year-old after the FA Cup final.

Although Collyer didn't make the squad for the FA Cup final, he travelled to Wembley and was on the pitch at the final whistle. Ten Hag exchanged words with him and the moment was reminiscent of his conversation with Kobbie Mainoo after the Carabao Cup final in 2023.
In the following campaign, Mainoo enjoyed his breakout season and it felt significant that Ten Hag took the time to speak to Collyer, who was given a new contract weeks later.
Collyer was rewarded with a new deal in July that extended his stay until 2027 and Ten Hag insisted on attending his contract signing, which further confirmed his admiration.

Ten Hag's admiration for the youngster has not surprised academy coaches and Under-21 manager Travis Binnion recently told the Manchester Evening News: "If Toby had a clean 18 months and a clean two-and-a-half years with us, we would be talking about a really top young player.

"We’re talking about a really good young player with high potential. He joined us from another club [Brighton] and took a little while to get going. He couldn’t play in the FA Youth Cup run, so he was here but couldn’t play. He's also had a couple of injuries and nothing terrible.

"But when you have a spell out of the game and have a couple of injuries that stop you playing, it takes a while to get going, but when we signed him, we had no doubts about what he was capable of - he's a fantastic athlete and effective without the ball.
"Toby is also making great strides with the ball, so we’re talking there about someone who can be really effective in all moments of the game and I think that’s what you saw on tour.
"That's why the manager has involved him in numerous squads. I think he’s earned the trust of the manager and that’s not easy to do, so great credit to him, he’s a fantastic lad.

"He's got a superb attitude and he’s getting what he deserves. We just know the manager really likes him and the conversations I have with Fletch [Darren Fletcher] are along those lines and we talk about what’s right for his development, so what’s next and what does he need to do?"

The opportunity to sign Collyer from Brighton arose unexpectedly in 2022. He was regarded as one of the finest midfielders in the country in his age group and a source at United has admitted they were surprised to get the chance to sign him - but they were delighted that they did.
Collyer was born in Worthing, which is around 10 miles from Brighton, and he was destined to break into the first team at the Amex Stadium until he was let go from the club.
Justin Cochrane, who now works for Brentford, was the head of player development and coaching at United's academy when Collyer signed and he was instrumental in the move.
Cochrane had worked with Collyer during his time with England's youth teams and the midfielder might have picked another Premier League club to join without his involvement.
Collyer had to deal with the disappointment of leaving Brighton, but that blow was softened by United, Manchester City, Chelsea and Tottenham enquiring to sign him.
The youngster's pre-existing relationship with Cochrane was a large factor in his relocation to Manchester, along with advice he received from mentors and some of his former coaches.

One of the coaches who advised Collyer to move north was Mark Beard, who managed different youth age groups at Brighton during his time at the club, including their Under-18s. "I was made aware of Toby probably from around the age of Under-14s," Beard told the MEN.

"I was the U18 manager and he used to come up and train with us, despite being much younger and I gave him his debut toward the end of his Under-15 year. He was always a little bit smaller back then and he seemed to shoot up in height suddenly when he became a scholar.
"Everyone would say he was the best player in the age group every year, but he was just one of them that you hardly noticed. He just got on with his job, there was no trouble and he worked hard.

"You wanted 11 Toby Collyers in your team because he’d work his socks off, run 13km a game and he took everything on board like a sponge. There were obviously a few things as he got older that we needed to work on and as he shot up a bit and he needed to redevelop.
"Toby sort of changed the way he played, so different types of passing, defending and he became a real good all-round midfielder once he'd learnt those two of three key areas.

"He could do two jobs in one. He could cover a position where he had a man to his left and a man to his right, and he could stay in the middle and if it was played to the right, he could get there and close the player down and would nick it. And his ball retention was different class.
