"You don't get midfielders like him anymore, he was sort of like a Kante for Leicester, the holding mids who just sit there. You don’t notice them and they let the flair players do their bit.

"He breaks play up well, he’s good defensively, strong, quick, his fitness levels are different class and his passing range is really good, which is what we worked on. Because he’s such a good passer, we wanted him to use it more, switch the play, and that will come with confidence and more experience."

Beard continued: "I had such a good team at Brighton with Evan Ferguson and players like that, and everyone would say Evan was unbelievable, but he’d touch the ball 10 times, score a goal and run about 8km.
"Toby would run around 13km every single game, he’d have 200 touches of the ball and have the best defensive duel win-rate. His stats would be astronomical, honestly, absolutely ridiculous.
"You really don’t get that with many players. He’d be under the radar, but those are the players you want in your team more than anyone else because they’re a dying breed.

"You need balance in a team and if you had three Kobbie Mainoos, you can't play them all. You need a combination and Toby will do stuff Mainoo won’t. He will break the play up and get the ball to Mainoo, so I think Man United have missed a player like this for quite a while.

"He’s young and you can’t put too much pressure on him, but he can be a big player eventually because he does that horrible defensive side of the game that not a lot of midfielders who are brought up through the academy system at clubs want to do anymore.
"Everyone wanted to sign him and he didn’t deserve the treatment he got at Brighton in the end. I told Toby you've got to sign for United when he asked for advice.

"I said Chelsea won’t give you a chance because they’ve got 700 players and Tottenham aren’t known for bringing kids through. I said United was the place for him and it wasn’t just me who said it, there were a few others who gave him that advice and he’s done amazing."
Collyer stayed in digs near Carrington when he joined United from Brighton two years ago - he was just 18 years old - but his decision to move 250 miles away from home is paying off.

Collyer's athleticism has made a strong impression at United and he is seen as a player who has a role to play in the first-team squad this season. A source has described him as 'very professional' and said he puts in a lot of work in the gym, regularly going in after training sessions.

He is known by members of staff to be confident but not a loud character and has been praised for his politeness and all-round good nature. United's academy intends to raise good people as well as excellent footballers and Collyer couldn't conduct himself better in all aspects.
But beyond Collyer's freakish running stats and good character, there is a very talented and highly regarded player who could offer something in midfield that United have been lacking.
Collyer is in the mould of a Michael Carrick or Darren Fletcher and should receive more first-team opportunities with Casemiro slowing down and showing signs of decline at 32 years old.
He replaced Casemiro against Liverpool and could be his long-term replacement at the club.

headline: I was at Manchester United the last time they had to rebuild - this is what they must do now
body: Manchester United's latest batch of new arrivals will know what they've been signed up to do. The short-term aims might be more low-key, but everyone at Old Trafford has one end goal in sight and that is to finally win the league again.

England's most successful domestic club have now gone 11 years without a title and the manager and group of players who finally deliver top spot once again will forever be feted as heroes. The 20-time champions have been here before, however.

Winning the league has proved to be beyond David Moyes, Louis van Gaal, Jose Mourinho, Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and quite possibly Erik ten Hag. Just as it was beyond the five permanent managers between the era of Sir Matt Busby and Sir Alex Ferguson.

That was a drought that stretched 26 years but Ferguson finally brought the good times back and re-established United as the undisputed kings of English football, although it took him a while to turn the club around.

Viv Anderson saw the start of that journey at close quarters. He was Ferguson's first signing in the summer of 1987 and although he had left by the time the first title arrived in 1993, he had seen enough to know the Scot was getting things right.

He had been at United as a schoolboy before being released but after a decade at Nottingham Forest and Arsenal the chance to return to Old Trafford was too good to turn down. As United ponder how to rebuild a title-winning machine under the stewardship of Ineos, Anderson's recollections of the late 1980s show just how hard it can be, as well as the importance of patience.

"I'd been at Manchester United many years before that and I knew what the club represents and I wanted to take that next step," he said. "Alex was really, really adamant about the way he wanted to play and the disciplines he wanted to be in and I thought, yeah, this is going to be a good club to work for under the stewardship of Alex."

Anderson, speaking to the Manchester Evening News at the launch of the latest Prostate United shirt challenge earlier this week, went on to make 69 appearances for the club before leaving for Sheffield Wednesday in 1991.

But it is the story of his arrival at Old Trafford that is more interesting than his departure. At a time when the current leadership has made a point of signing players with a winning attitude and the right personality to play for United, Anderson was recruited for similar reasons. All it took to catch the eye of Ferguson was one minor skirmish in an Arsenal vs United fixture.
"I always remember Bryan Robson saying to me, 'the only reason he bought you is because you stood up to Norman Whiteside when we were playing for Arsenal'," said Anderson.

"So he [Whiteside] got David Rocastle, who is sadly no longer with us, sent off in that game at Old Trafford. We were coming there on a run of 13 unbeaten games and we just got kicked from pillar to post and me and Norman had a little scuffle from time to time and [Ferguson] saw that I stood up to Norman, he was a big superstar at the time, and liked what he saw."

When Anderson arrived in 1987 United were still six years away from ending that wait for a league title. Ferguson had taken over in November 1986 and the club had finished 11th in the old First Division that season.

These days, most managers will lay out a philosophy to new signings, a plan to get a club to where they want to be and the role that player will play. When Anderson spoke to Ferguson, it was more straightforward.
"He said he bought me because he saw what he saw that day [against Arsenal] and he looked at my record," he said. "I didn't miss many games over my career and he was very strong on that.

"He liked people that were going to be there week in, week out and subsequently, I get there and get injured and miss a lot of games so it doesn't always work out. People going to that club, the expectations are massive and you've got to embrace it or you fold."

Ferguson suffered from those expectations. United finished second in his first full season, then 11th and 13th. In that third season, 1989/90, there were stories the manager was going to be sacked if they lost to Nottingham Forest in the FA Cup third round.

"I remember playing at Forest in the FA Cup tie and prior to the game they were talking about Fergie out and this and that and the other," said Anderson. "And we won the game. Mark Robins scored and we ended up going to the final that year and winning it and the rest is history.

"That game, we talked about it, but internally we never thought it was going to happen because he'd been there such a short period of time. It would always be difficult to get rid of managers at that time, you know, in the 80s, to get rid of a manager who hadn't been there that long.
"So we never thought it was going to happen. But we managed to win that day and, as I say, go on to win the cup that year."

That fixture at the City Ground in January 1990 - now one of the most well-known stories in the club's history - came when United were on a run of eight league fixtures without a win. They would lose the two straight after the FA Cup win as well, against Derby and Norwich.

So Anderson gets what it is like to play in a United team that isn't delivering, one that is under pressure and underperforming. This is a club with the history to expect titles, so when standards dip as they had then and have done again now, it can become difficult.
"I know what it's like to be at a club like Man United and get all the stick they're getting at the moment and it's hard going," he said.
"But you've got to get through it and the only way you can do it is by putting in decent performances. There's always going to be expectations at all the football clubs.

"You go to Arsenal, where I went, you can never be as good as the double winners. You go to Man United, you're never going to be as good as Best, Law and Charlton. So there are things you've got to get over and if you want to play for Manchester United you've got to take them on board and embrace it and try and do better or equal these people.

"[It's a hard club to manage] because of the expectations. Expectations, but from the supporters, from everybody connected with Manchester United whether it's abroad, at home, they expect to play in a certain way and they expect to win. And if they don't win, they make their feelings felt."
Ferguson did, of course, eventually get it right. Anderson had left the club when the good times really started to roll but he sensed it was on the right track.

"I think he inherited some players that people in the building thought they were going to be half-decent players. Some didn't live up to expectations and so he had to persevere with those to see if the people who'd thought that were right," he said.
"Then he had the Giggs, Butts, Scholes, both Nevilles coming through, when we saw them playing you think these are gonna be proper players so it was a matter of time.

"He had those players coming through so Brian Kidd has to take a lot of credit for that and Eric Harrison, the people who scouted these players. How many do you get and you get those players I've mentioned, they go on to get 50, 60 caps for their country, they're very few and far between.

"They’re very exceptional players so the spade work had been done before him and he inherited these players, but he bought them through in the right way. Giggs, he wouldn't play many games, he'd come in, come out, same with the rest, he nurtured them really well to the level that right now you're good enough to start every game. They were superstars after all."
Ferguson did it all back then. As Anderson says, he was the manager, the scout, the director of football. The game is very different now.

One example of Ferguson's ability to think outside the box and make the most of people who had played for him was his role for Anderson early in the club's European adventures, when he would come back to offer some advice to the youngsters.
"I came back for European games when the [Class of 92] were playing, just to give them my experience of playing in European games. So I used to come back from Sheffield way," he said.
"I just used to talk to them about those games, I'd been to the level that they were striving to get to, so any words of advice I could give them I would do."

Right now it would take a leap of faith to believe Ten Hag is on a similar path to Ferguson and although Anderson insists United can't keep changing the manager, he accepts it is time for the Dutchman to deliver.

"He’s changed his backroom staff, they've given him money, it's now time to perform," he said. "It's really important that United get back to winning ways. Bad start but you know, top four is really important, Champions League has got to be paramount for the players and the manager, so that proves success which we didn't have last year."
Anderson is still a regular back at Old Trafford and he was in Manchester earlier this week helping to launch the new Prostate United shirt ahead of their latest fundraising initiative.

The 68-year-old could still fit into the striking kit as he spoke to the Manchester Evening News at the event. Since its launch in 2018, the Prostate United event has seen over 60 football clubs - both professional and non-league - hundreds of club staff and now fans, walk, run or cycle every day during the month of October to save men’s lives.

"It's the launch of the shirt, and as it says on the front, 45 minutes of a football match, one person dies of prostate cancer every 45 minutes," said Anderson. "When you put it in perspective like that it is quite scary."
Anybody raising £500 for the charity will be able to get their hands on a shirt this season and supporters can sign up for the challenge here.

headline: Manchester United have a clone of £39m Newcastle star ready to be unleashed from academy
body: Manchester United fans always wonder which youngster from the academy might be the next to make their senior debut.
There have been 251 youngsters from the academy to make first-team debuts at Old Trafford and that is an extraordinary club achievement that is worth shouting about.
Toby Collyer is the most recent academy product to have made his senior bow and perhaps Ethan Ennis, who has three goals in four games this season, could be the next.

It was a big deal when United signed Ennis from Liverpool in August 2021. He scored 10 goals in 19 appearances for United's Under-18s in 2021/22, his first full season at the club, but disaster struck a year later when he ruptured the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) in his knee.
ACL injuries are feared by footballers and can have devastating consequences on a career, but Ennis has made a full recovery and was gradually eased back into action last season.

Last term was about Ennis finding his feet again - this season is about him finding his groove again. The 19-year-old has been in outstanding form, scoring for the U21s against Arsenal, Barnsley and Blackburn, and he's been present in first-team training sessions at Carrington.
Ennis looked sharp in friendlies against Rosenborg and Rangers this summer, coming on from the bench under the watchful eye of Erik ten Hag, and is a dynamic winger worth keeping a look out for.
He is beginning to make up for lost time after his serious knee injury and a source has said his professionalism in and out of training hasn't gone unnoticed at United.

Ennis signed a new United contract this summer, as his previous deal with the club expired in the summer of 2025, and it's understood he's been challenged to deliver consistently strong displays - throughout the entire 90 minutes of a match - by coaches in the academy.
The youngster is currently rising to that challenge and making improvements to his game, which means he's putting himself in contention to make a first-team debut this season.

United decided it would be best for Ennis' development for him to spend the first half of the season with the Under-21s before his situation was assessed in January - he could benefit from a loan - but there might be a chance to make a debut in a cup competition before then.
There is a lot to like about Ennis. He has the physical build of a professional footballer, he glides with the ball on the wing and his finishing ability is one of his finest qualities.
Ennis is a goalscoring winger and knows where the net is, and one United fan recently compared his style to Andrei Kanchelskis, who signed for Sir Alex Ferguson in 1991.
Coaches argue that comparisons are unhelpful and reiterate a player is an individual and unique to themselves, but they can provide insight into how a youngster might develop.
The Kanchelskis comparison has merit, but there's actually a player currently in the Premier League who Ennis is eerily similar to and that is Newcastle winger Harvey Barnes.
Barnes is not a name that will excite United fans, but he has proven himself in the top flight with Leicester and Newcastle and is a winger who possesses excellent finishing ability.
Leicester sold the 26-year-old to Newcastle in a deal worth £39million in 2023 and United would love Ennis, who has similar qualities as a winger, to develop similarly.

Not many wingers have such a knack for finding the back of the net. It's worth following an academy game to watch how Ennis strikes a ball and he is potent when cutting inside or arriving in the box, which is a brilliant skill to have as an emerging young player in the academy.
Comparisons with Barnes might be sniffed at but it's a compliment to Ennis.
Hello all and welcome to the Manchester United transfer blog as we sit one week away from the Premier League returning.

There may be no competitive football taking place this weekend in the top flight but United fans will be descending on Old Trafford this afternoon as a Legends XI which includes Wayne Rooney, takes on a Celtic XI to raise money for the Manchester United Foundation. While a host of greats will be on the pitch today for a worthy cause, Erik ten Hag will be keen to keep one eye on his senior squad.

With the Turkish transfer window closing on September 18, a lot of reports are circulating around United players who could be shipped off. Antony is currently being linked with a loan move to Jose Mourinho's Fenerbahce while Casemiro has been tipped to join Galatasaray.

Neither man has had the start to the season they would have wanted but it will be intriguing to see if either Turkish club would be able to do enough to tempt them to leave the Reds. Meanwhile, United received a timely boost this week as Leny Yoro stepped up his rehabilitation from injury.
The centre-back no longer requires crutches to walk as he looks to get himself back in contention sooner rather than later.
Follow our live updates below for all the latest news from Old Trafford...
While it may seem that Ugarte is in the prime position to take over from Casemiro permanently, Keane believes there is still a place in the squad for the Brazilian.
He told Stick to Football, brought to you by Sky Bet:

I wouldn’t be writing him off yet. Maybe his role in the team if he gets back in, gets a couple of games under his belt, might be higher up the pitch. The first thing we always say is that he can’t get around the pitch but when you see him going forward he does have an eye for a pass and set-pieces, how many times do you see him get his head on it? Will Casemiro get Man United back to competing with Man City? Of course not. But the deal is done, he’s at the club.
Following the international break, United will travel to the South Coast for a tricky clash with Southampton in the Premier League.
The midfield could look different to the one which started the clash with Liverpool last weekend.
Casemiro is almost certain to be dropped after being subbed at half-time and replaced by debutant Ugarte.
The Uruguayan will probably partner Mainoo in the holding midfield roles with Fernandes more advanced.
According to Give Me Sport, both Casemiro and Eriksen have been informed that this season will be their last at Old Trafford as United look to make further improvements to their midfield.
It is believed sporting director Dan Ashworth has been set the task of finding younger players to replace the midfield duo at Old Trafford.
Eriksen is out of contract at the end of the season while Casemiro's deal runs until 2026.
United's new signing Manuel Ugarte impressed for Uruguay overnight as they drew 0-0 with Paraguay in a World Cup qualifier.
Despite not picking up the three points, Ugarte will be pleased with his efforts in defensive midfield.
Ugarte may not have had the pre-season he had hoped for but he showed no signs of ill effects for Marcelo Bielsa's men.
READ MORE HERE
Like Antony, Casemiro is looking to dig in his heels and avoid being sold this month to Galatasaray.
According to the Daily Mail, Casemiro is determined to fight for his place at Old Trafford even though it appears likely Manuel Ugarte will take his place in the starting line-up.
It is believed in December former football director John Murtough travelled to Saudi Arabia to gauge interest in buying the Brazilian midfielder but any concrete interest was not forthcoming.
United winger Antony pledged to MEN Sport at the beginning of August that we would see his name connected with goals and assists this season.

Unfortunately for the 24-year-old, his ability to keep this promise has so far been hampered by a lack of opportunities in the first team. The Brazilian winger has played just one minute in four matches so far this season and has had to settle for a place on the bench as the likes of; Marcus Rashford, Amad and Alejandro Garnacho have been entrusted to run the wings.

In the dying embers of the Community Shield penalty shootout defeat to bitter rivals Manchester City, manager Erik ten Hag even turned to now-Chelsea winger Jadon Sancho ahead of the Brazilian when he assessed his options off the bench. During the international break, reports have suggested a loan move to Turkey could be on the cards for Antony with Jose Mourinho's Fenerbahce reportedly keen to give him a chance.

There is more than a week left of the Turkish window so it does provide an opportunity for United to loan out their stars. However, is this the best move for Antony or United? MEN Sport has asked its United writers to provide their suggestions for the winger.
READ WHAT OUR WRITERS HAD TO SAY HERE
It is admirable that Antony wishes to remain at United and fight for his place in the starting XI.
However, it must be stressed that just because a player wishes to stay at Old Trafford does not mean they will necessarily get their wish.

Antony is clearly out of favour at the moment and United may see a loan until January as advantageous for all parties especially as it would give him an opportunity to be fresh and firing for the second half of the season.
Speaking earlier this year, the 24-year-old's agent Junior Pedroso was adamant that Antony had made his intentions to stay at United clear:
I see reports about a potential exit on loan. Antony’s plan is clear: Manchester United. He wants to stay, he’s only focused on Man United. We already spoke about that with the club.
It is believed that United's Antony is wanted by Mourinho this summer as Fenerbahce look to strengthen their attack.
The 24-year-old has struggled for opportunities so far this campaign having played just one minute in the Premier League.
However, the Brazilian is believed to have already made his mind up about any offers from elsewhere.
Hello and welcome back to the United transfer blog this Saturday.

There may not be any competitive action for the Reds this weekend but we will be providing you with all the latest news, views and transfer rumours throughout the morning as Ten Hag's men prepare for next week's return.
We shall also be providing updates from Old Trafford as United's Legends take on Celtic Legends in a charity match with proceeds going towards the Manchester United Foundation.
It promises to be another busy day so make sure you keep across everything that is happening here.
Probably no surprise here, and we know of the possible switch to represent Jamaica as well, but Lee Carsley said Mason Greenwood was not considered for this England squad.
Here's a recap of the day's biggest talking points:
Anthony Martial is still looking for a new club.
He is in talks with Brazilian side Flamengo, Fabrizio Romano reports, with the forward one of the main targets for the remainder of the window.
No United involvement in the Nations League this evening but here are the games going on.
Hello there.
Tom Coley here to take you through to the close of play.
The international football is about to kick off for the night so I'll have the top stories (below) and a full recap of the day's biggest topics, to come.
In their seven months in charge at Manchester United Ineos have shown that the attraction of working at Old Trafford remains as strong as ever, despite the club's on-pitch struggles.
For those working in the background, the challenge of restoring United to the pinnacle of the domestic game is clearly an attractive one.
Sir Jim Ratcliffe set out the ambition of recruiting the 'best in class' and he has been as good as his word.
Ajax talent Anton Gaaei has admitted his disappointment that rumours linking Christian Eriksen back to a return to Amsterdam did not come to fruition.
The Dane left Ajax for Tottenham in 2013 before going on to play for Inter Milan and Brentford before being signed by United.
Gaaei told Tipsbladet:

"Of course, you hope for (the transfer to happen) when such a good Dane is written about. He is one of the best in the Nordics. So I hoped for that, but it didn’t happen. Now, we just have to do it as well as possible.”

For the second summer in a row, Manchester United didn't spend a transfer fee on a player older than 27 as they look to pivot towards a strategy that focuses on those either in their prime or yet to hit their highest level.
Those windows have come under two different models and if it was perhaps coincidental in 2023, it's a clear shift in 2024 in what was Ineos' first summer as the primary decision-makers at the club.
Their £200m spree saw an 18-year-old, two 23-year-olds, a 25-year-old and a 26-year-old arrive.
Manchester United successfully managed to strengthen their midfield in the summer transfer window with the late signing of Manuel Ugarte.
Erik ten Hag plays a midfield three with Fernandes often joining the forward line. However, United are often short when the Portugal playmaker is unavailable.
Fortunately, despite the transfer window closing a week ago, sporting director Dan Ashworth could still register an attacking midfielder.
Manchester United defender Leny Yoro is walking without crutches as he steps up his rehabilitation from a foot injury.
Yoro fractured his metatarsal in the first half of the 2-1 defeat to Arsenal in Los Angeles, which was the opening fixture of United's pre-season tour in the United States.
The 18-year-old underwent surgery at the beginning of August to address the problem and November was earmarked for his return.
Adrien Rabiot has long been linked with United, and even saw the club agree a pre-agreement with Juventus in 2022 before talks broke down.
The midfielder is still a free agent having left Turin at the end of his contract upon the conclusion of last season. The Frenchman has been linked with a number of outfits but remains unemployed.

A report from Teamtalk claims United are still admirers of Rabiot and are in the mix to sign him although face competition from Newcastle. The report claims Galatasaray have tabled an offer before the player.
Manchester United's exciting youngster Shea Lacey could return to action after the international break.
The Manchester Evening News understands Lacey has been sidelined with a muscle injury but has made progress in his recovery and will be in contention to play after the break.
Lacey is in contention to feature for the Under-18s against Newcastle on Saturday, September 14 and it's thought he will be carefully handled and eased back into action.
Followers of the academy are looking forward to Lacey's return, but United will not rush the youngster, who last made an appearance in April, back from his injury.
Read more here
Former Arsenal, Chelsea and Tottenham defender William Gallas has offered his verdict on Erik ten Hag's future at Old Trafford.

"Manchester United, from what I’ve seen, have very little chance of finishing in the top four this season. In all honesty I don’t think it will be long before Erik ten Hag is sacked," Gallas told Gambling Zone.
"How can they lose 3-0 at home to Liverpool? Their former players must be mad after what they saw during that game at Old Trafford. It’s simply not acceptable.
"If they lose to Southampton and he’s sacked, I won’t be surprised. They’ve made more new signings and now it’s his third season.
"Maybe Manchester United is too big a club for Erik ten Hag. The pressure is too much for him."
Emmanuel Petit has expressed his frustration over Jadon Sancho's decision to become Chelsea's latest addition on deadline day.

"When I saw they had signed Jadon Sancho on Deadline Day, I wondered if there was even any shirt numbers left for him," Petit told sports betting site BetVictor (via football.london). "Imagine him opening the door to the dressing room and seeing so many players they don't all fit in the same dressing room! At the training ground they must have two dressing rooms, three pitches and 12 physios.

"The club are not the only ones responsible for the situation. It also comes down to the players. How can Sancho bring himself to sign for Chelsea after what happened at Manchester United? He was loaned to Borussia Dortmund, then went back to United, and now he's off to Chelsea who have 40 or so players and he is just one of them."
Read more here
In their seven months in charge at Manchester United Ineos have shown that the attraction of working at Old Trafford remains as strong as ever, despite the club's on-pitch struggles.

For those working in the background, the challenge of restoring United to the pinnacle of the domestic game is clearly an attractive one. Sir Jim Ratcliffe set out the ambition of recruiting the 'best in class' and he has been as good as his word.

Ineos appointed Omar Berrada from Manchester City and Dan Ashworth from Newcastle United to fill their two most important roles and Jason Wilcox swapped a job as a director of football at Southampton to become United's technical director.
Read the full opinion piece here
Cristiano Ronaldo was visibly moved to tears after scoring his landmark 900th career goal during Portugal's clash with Croatia on Thursday night.

The Al-Nassr star found the back of the net just before half-time, giving the Selecao a lead at the interval in their UEFA Nations League opener. Manchester United defender Diogo Dalot had put Roberto Martinez's team ahead earlier, but an own goal from the full-back made it 2-1 at half-time.

Ronaldo's strike marked his 131st for Portugal, adding to the 769 he has amassed at club level. This milestone followed a challenging Euro 2024 campaign where he experienced the disappointment of a penalty miss against Slovenia.
Read more here
Roy Keane has already offered his verdict on Antony's future amid reports linking him with a move away from Manchester United.
The Brazilian has failed to live up to expectations since completing a move to Old Trafford in 2022. Antony has scored 11 goals and provided just five assists in 83 appearances for the Reds.
Recent reports have claimed that Turkish club Fenerbahce are interested in a loan move for the 24-year-old. It is said that former United boss Jose Mourinho is keen to sign the winger.
Read what Keane had to say here
Former United striker Michael Owen believes the club's treatment of Jadon Sancho has cost them millions.
"The Jadon Sancho situation was a mess, it has been right from the outset," he told TVSporten.

"How can you pay what you've paid for Jadon Sancho and then have a huge argument and then all of a sudden, a year later, decide to clear the air. All the while paying the bulk of his wages even when he was out on loan.
"During that time he’s another year down on his contract. So the whole process has probably cost the club £20 million since the argument on top of his fee.

"And that’s just because you're too stubborn to have that chat and clear the air. It just feels a mess right from the start - and, after seemingly having spoken and sorted out the differences, he still wasn't in favour."
A report in Turkey claims Manchester United agreed a loan deal with Galatasaray for Casemiro on Wednesday but the player rejected the prospect, vowing to fight for his place at Old Trafford.

There is scepticism around the report from outlet Turkiye Gazetesi, given the Brazilian was included in United’s Europa League squad submission earlier this week, indicating that an exit was not imminent.

The Turkish transfer window does not shut until September 13, meaning United could still sell Casemiro to a Super Lig club despite the English deadline passing last Friday. And The Times claims that Galatasaray are indeed mulling over a move for the 32-year-old.
Read more here
Jurgen Klopp has expressed his disapproval of Manchester United's handling of Jadon Sancho, emphasising that a manager should support their players rather than discard them as "useless".
The former Liverpool manager remarked before the transfer deadline: "If the whole world loses trust and faith in the player, the manager has to be the one behind the player.
"I cannot just buy into that 'he's useless,' like other clubs did by the way - buying a player for £80 million and then sending him out on loan!"
Read more here

headline: Manuel Ugarte sends clear message to Erik ten Hag ahead of potential Man United debut
body: Manchester United's new signing Manuel Ugarte showed Erik ten Hag exactly what he can offer his new team as he put in a masterclass in Uruguay's World Cup qualifier vs Paraguay.

The former PSG man arrived at Old Trafford on deadline day after a prolonged saga that threatened to stretch United's patience. Eventually, United managed to shake hands on an initial fee of £42m for the midfielder but this figure could rise to £50.5m depending whether or not certain clauses are reached.

Ugarte was in attendance last Sunday as he watched his new teammates put in a horror performance to lose 3-0 to Liverpool at Old Trafford. The 23-year-old's direct competition for a place in the starting line-up Casemiro had a particularly difficult afternoon as he made two mistakes which led to two goals.

He was substituted at half-time for youngster Toby Collyer in a strong statement by Ten Hag. Ahead of the Premier League's return next weekend, all eyes are on the manager to decide whether or not to give Casemiro another chance or choose to trust Ugarte.

Overnight, Ugarte did little to harm his chances of being picked at St Mary's Stadium as he produced a brilliant performance in defensive midfield. While Casemiro lacked some spacial awareness in defeat to Liverpool last weekend, Ugarte looked in his element just in front of the backline as he helped deal with Paraguay's press.

Ugarte was also doing his bit to prevent counter attacks too putting in some impressive last ditch tackles to evade dangerous opportunities for the opposition. While the game ended goalless, the midfielder will be pleased with his contributions that lasted 79 minutes in total.
This display will no doubt cause a headache for Ten Hag ahead of the clash with the Saints next Saturday.

headline: Why Roy Keane won't be playing in Man United Legends match vs Celtic at Old Trafford
body: Manchester United icon Roy Keane has already explained why he does not compete in charity matches these days despite two of his old teams facing off at Old Trafford on Saturday afternoon.

Keane made a whopping 475 appearances for the Reds during his illustrious playing career before making the switch to Celtic where he retired after just 11 matches for the Glasgow club. Due to his legendary status in football, it would be expected that the 53-year-old would be one of the first players asked to play in the Manchester United Foundation match this weekend.

However, the ex-midfielder will not be playing after admitting a couple of years ago that his fitness levels are not at the required standard to return to the pitch. In an interview with Off the Ball, he explained: "I'm not fit. I'm far from fit.
"My fitness levels are actually very, very embarrassing. Just because I've not put on loads of weight doesn't mean to say I'm fit.
"I wouldn't really be able to do any running. Put it this way, I've been invited a number of times over the last few years to play legends games or whatever you want to call it.
"I'd find it really difficult because I wouldn't be able to get around. Too many injury problems.

"I try to have a decent diet obviously and I'm wary of putting on too much weight, but I certainly wouldn't be fit enough to go on any sort of run." Just a month after this interview, Keane made a surprise appearance for United in a charity match against Liverpool at Anfield where he was given the full pantomime reception from the home crowds.
However, this was seen as a one-off and he has not put on the United kit again since. Keane is not in the country today either as he is a pundit for ITV Sport's England coverage.
The Three Lions face Keane's Republic of Ireland on Saturday evening in the Nations League and the popular Red will be part of their panel covering the match.

headline: 'He returned' - Manchester United to receive double injury boost that could change season
body: “We have to see how it develops and how we can progress during the break, to get match fit,” said Erik ten Hag about Rasmus Hojlund before Manchester United's last game.
“He returned on the pitch but it will take a while before he is up. Everyone has seen, it [the injury] happens in the first game [pre-season tour], so he needs also to build some fitness.”

Around 30 minutes after Ten Hag's press conference, Hojlund drove out of Carrington, wearing shaded sunglasses in his Range Rover, and stopped for autographs and photos. "I pulled my hamstring but I'm okay now," said Hojlund when a small child who was wearing a United replica with his name and number asked why he hadn't played this season.

Hojlund has returned to training on the grass at Carrington, which usually indicates a return to full training is around two weeks away and that is excellent news for United, who have sorely missed his presence in attack in the opening few games of the new Premier League season.

Bruno Fernandes has been used as a false nine and Joshua Zirkzee started down the middle against Liverpool but Hojlund is a natural centre-forward and is more effective in that role. What he brings to the team, being able to stretch a defence with his pace and getting in behind the opposition, is unique and the injury he sustained in pre-season was unfortunate.

Hojlund tweaked his hamstring after opening the scoring against Arsenal in Los Angeles and his goal was the type nobody else in the United squad could produce - he used his body brilliantly, shielded the ball with his strength and used his acceleration to evade his marker.

The 21-year-old is built in the mould of a traditional striker and if his finishing has improved for this season, he has the ability to significantly better his haul of 16 goals last term. Hojlund's return will be a huge boost and he is expected to be available against Southampton when football resumes after the international break. United are guaranteed to create chances against the relegation candidates and Hojlund could mark his return with a bang.

Whether Luke Shaw returns to the squad alongside Hojlund at St Mary's remains to be seen. The defender hasn't played for United this season, despite playing for England at Euro 2024, and Ten Hag didn't give an update on his situation at his latest press conference.
United said on August 13 that Shaw would miss the opening games of the Premier League season due to a calf injury sustained at the start of pre-season training.

The clash against Southampton comes on September 14 and four weeks should be enough time to recover from a calf strain, providing it's not serious. That teases the possibility of Shaw and Hojlund making the XI on the south coast.

United have scraped past Fulham, defeated by Brighton and hammered by Liverpool, which has made the Southampton game an early season must-win encounter with the following three matches challenging. Crystal Palace away, Tottenham at home and Aston Villa away await and United must get back to winning ways to ease pressure on Ten Hag.

The chances of breezing past Southampton with minimal fuss will increase if Hojlund and Shaw are back from the sidelines. They are two hugely important players in how Ten Hag wants to play and the latter's passing qualities are particularly important for building up from the back.

Ten Hag will give a fresh update on Hojlund and Shaw at his press conference on Thursday and fans will be desperately hoping he confirms their return to action against Southampton. It's also imperative that when they return to fitness, they maintain a clean bill of health.

headline: Ineos have given Erik ten Hag something he's always wanted at Manchester United
body: In their seven months in charge at Manchester United Ineos have shown that the attraction of working at Old Trafford remains as strong as ever, despite the club's on-pitch struggles.

For those working in the background, the challenge of restoring United to the pinnacle of the domestic game is clearly an attractive one. Sir Jim Ratcliffe set out the ambition of recruiting the 'best in class' and he has been as good as his word.

Ineos appointed Omar Berrada from Manchester City and Dan Ashworth from Newcastle United to fill their two most important roles and Jason Wilcox swapped a job as a director of football at Southampton to become United's technical director.

Christopher Vivell was coming in off the back of a short and infilling spell at Chelsea but the German still had a reputation as one of the shrewdest talent-spotters and recruitment experts in the game. On Monday, another former Manchester City employee will walk into the club on the opposite side of town.

Recruiting Sam Erith as interim performance director is a significant feather in the cap for Ineos. Erith spent 11 years at City as head of sports science and lead for human performance. Erith was highly regarded at the Etihad and held similar roles with Tottenham and the England national team.
He can be a significant asset for United and will work to create an elite performance environment around Carrington, focusing on the first-team squad and supporting Erik ten Hag.

This is now a very different club than the one Ten Hag walked into in the summer of 2022 and found to be underpowered. Ralf Rangnick had flagged some of these issues to United and his permanent replacement has spoken of the culture and environment he inherited.
"So I think in general when I came in at Man United, the standards were not right. That’s true," Ten Hag said in the summer of 2023.

"I demand the highest standards in sleep, recovery and nutrition because that makes the difference if you can perform every third or fourth day. That is the demand for every top football player, so at Man United we are demanding the highest standards."

Some of that is on the players but when you look at the depth of the structure now at the club, compared to 2022, it's hardly surprising they were falling short. John Murtough had only just appointed Andy O'Boyle as his deputy and they were spreading themselves too thin.

How that has changed now. Ten Hag has all the support he needs, both in terms of recruitment and more general support. He speaks to Wilcox almost daily and will now benefit from Erith's expertise in creating elite environments.
Ten Hag spoke in July about how his role had narrowed - for the better - and that is allowing him to commit a greater focus to training, improving players and developing a game model.
"That basis has been greatly strengthened. A lot has been taken away from me in scouting and recruitment. That is necessary," he told AD.

“You need a very strong structure in scouting and transfer policy. I can only be happy that I have Dan (Ashworth), Jason (Wilcox) and Christopher (Vivell) at my side. The club has acquired incredible know-how and knowledge of the market that helps me.
“We have only been working with these new people for a few weeks but Ashworth is close by – a room away. The new owners take me more into the process. It’s early days but the signs are very good.”
Since that interview, the structure around Ten Hag has been strengthened further. Now he can focus on his primary job, which is shaping a team that can deliver results.

headline: Manchester United favourite being played out of position is worse than it seems
body: In the spring, Aaron Wan-Bissaka played at left-back for Manchester United when it seemed like the best option was to play Diogo Dalot there, given his versatility and attributes.
Wan-Bissaka at right-back and Dalot at left-back would have been the selection of most fans in the circumstances, but Erik ten Hag thought differently and was coy when asked about the decision.

"I can't go too deep in that fact," said Ten Hag. "But they have both, of course, their skills, their contribution to the team, so we have a clear idea of what is ideally [the situation]. Sometimes, we have to adjust this but lately it has worked out very good, and we want to keep that consistency with Diogo and Garnacho on the right side because they have their connection.

"Also, Diogo, I know, has a very good connection with Antony. So, most of the times we want to keep such routines and that is why I chose lately for this partnership. To keep Diogo more on the right side and then, lately, Azza came in and did a very good job over on the left side."
Ten Hag explained as much as he could reveal and it seemed the thought process was that Dalot was performing so well on the right that it would be wrong to disrupt his rhythm.
Dalot has played at left-back during different stages of his career and is competent on that side, but Wan-Bissaka was chosen to play there for the first time in his career last season.

It's fair to say eyebrows were raised when Wan-Bissaka was initially played there in January. He is an excellent one-on-one defender, but he's hardly known for his technical ability, which suggested he might struggle to play in a position he'd never taken up before.

Fast forward to the September international break, Wan-Bissaka has left for West Ham and Dalot has started each Premier League game against Fulham, Brighton and Liverpool at left-back, with new signing Noussair Mazraoui playing on the right side of defence.
Sources said Mazraoui was signed because of his versatility, but he's got the nod at right-back and that has seen Dalot look out of sorts in the opening games of the season.
Although Dalot has plenty of experience of playing at left-back, his attacking threat is reduced when he doesn't start on the right and Mazraoui isn't compensating for that enough.

It's been fascinating to see Ten Hag play Dalot at left-back this term considering he was so adamant about playing Dalot on the right at the beginning of the year that he played Wan-Bissaka in a position he'd never played to keep him there - which was a statement in itself.
However, Mazraoui is comfortable on the left and it seems the best option to play him there and relocate Dalot to the right when football resumes after the international break.
The 25-year-old is often seen making overlapping runs and crossing the ball using his right foot when he starts there and he's unable to be as effective when starting on the left.
Dalot struggled with pacy Fulham winger Adama Traore in the opening clash, he improved against Brighton but regressed against Liverpool's fluid and impressive attack.

Casemiro's mistakes were responsible for Liverpool's goals in the first half, but Dalot couldn't prevent Mohamed Salah from providing the assists for Luis Diaz's brace and Mazraoui's positioning was questionable throughout, including for Trent Alexander-Arnold's disallowed goal.

If something isn't working, it makes sense to make a change and 'experimenting' against Southampton with Dalot at right-back and Mazraoui on the other side, providing Luke Shaw isn't back in the squad, is the best option based on the evidence of the games so far.
Dalot won the Players' Player of the Year award for his consistently strong performances last season and should return to his strongest position sooner rather than later.

headline: Shaw, Malacia, Hojlund - Man United injury news and return dates before Southampton
body: While it may be the international break, Manchester United will already be preparing for the return of Premier League football in just over a week.

Several members of the squad are currently off on international duty, but once those games are over attention will turn straight back to United’s clash against Southampton. United travel down to the south coast looking to bounce back from the disappointment of last week’s match against Liverpool.

The 3-0 defeat means that United have lost their last two games after winning their opening match against Fulham. The results place emphasis on the importance of taking all three points back with them from the game against the Saints.
The good news for United and Erik ten Hag is that the game could see them welcome some players back from injury. With that in mind, here is the latest from the treatment room at Carrington.
Injury: Foot

Yoro was ruled out for three months in the summer after suffering a fractured metatarsal in the 2-1 friendly defeat against Arsenal during pre-season. He was withdrawn in the first half of the game and now faces a wait to make his Manchester United debut.
Potential return date: Vs Ipswich (A) (23 November)
Injury: Knee
What Ten Hag has said: "He is now in a good place," Ten Hag said on August 2, "but he is not here because I only took players who could play games or be available for team training.
"He is not that far, but he is now in a progress situation. At a relatively short notice, he can again return into team training and then into team performance in games.
"I think it would be possible (for Malacia to return) in two months."
Potential return date: Vs Bretford (H) (19 October)
Injury: Hamstring

Mount said: "During the last game, I picked up a minor muscle issue. I've had it checked, and it looks like I'll be out for a few games. Leading up to and during pre-season, I worked hard to get my fitness back to where it needed to be, and I felt re-energised, sharp and ready. I wanted you to hear it directly from me how frustrated I am, as I expect you are, too. I will do everything possible to be back in the best shape and help the team.” (August 29)
Potential return date: Vs Aston Villa (A) (6 October)
Injury: Hamstring

What Ten Hag has said: “After the international break, but when? We will see how it develops during the break to get him match fit. It will take a while before he is up. He has to build some fitness.” (August 30)
Potential return date: Vs Crystal Palace (A) (21 September)
Injury: Toe
What Ten Hag has said: “He has an issue with his toe. Hopefully, he can return quickly, but he is not available for the weekend.” (August 22)
Potential return date: Vs Southampton (A) (14 September)
Injury: Calf

What Ten Hag has said: “I think he will return in the short term; it doesn't take long. We are looking forward, of course. Luke is massively important, so we want to get him back as soon as possible, but we can't force this process.” (August 15)
Potential return date: Vs Southampton (A) (14 September)

headline: Manuel Ugarte's Manchester United debut set as Erik ten Hag gets Casemiro solution
body: Manuel Ugarte is showing Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag he is fit enough to make his Premier League debut away at Southampton after the international break.

Ugarte, 23, started for Uruguay in their home World Cup qualifier against Paraguay on Friday night, playing the best part of 80 minutes before being substituted. It was the defensive midfielder's first match since starting for his country in the Copa America third-place play-off versus Canada in mid-July.

During the two months without playing, Ugarte spent some time on holiday after the tournament in the United States before returning for pre-season training with his then-club Paris Saint-Germain. He did not play upon his return, with a move to United in the works.
READ MORE:Dan Ashworth offered unique United transfer opportunity to unlock Bruno Fernandes
READ MORE:United have genius £51m transfer plan as dream Casemiro solution finally clear

But despite there being almost eight weeks between his last two matches, Ugarte did not show it, starring for Uruguay in the 0-0 draw in new head coach Gustavo Alfaro's debut. The defensive midfielder sat deep in a midfield three, flanked by Brian Rodriguez and Real Madrid's Federico Valverde.

He also played alongside former United winger Facundo Pellistri, who moved on during the summer transfer window, joining the Greek club Panathinaikos. The stalemate keeps Uruguay second in the South American standings after seven matches, with the top six qualifying for the 2026 World Cup.
They next play on Tuesday night away at Venezuela, who are five points behind them in fifth. Ugarte will thus seemingly return to England at some stage on Wednesday next week.

United then play Saturday lunchtime away at Southampton in the first match following the international break. With such a tight turnaround and Casemiro not being in the Brazil squad, Ten Hag could name Ugarte on the bench rather than in the starting lineup, but a Premier League debut for the summer signing during that match now seems likely.

headline: Man United eye 'two necessary transfers' as Ineos' Erik ten Hag stance clear
body: Manchester United are a week away from returning to Premier League action as the first international break of the season leaves the club with much to think about.

The Reds won their opening match of the campaign but back-to-back defeats, including a humbling 3-0 loss to Liverpool at Old Trafford have added pressure to all those associated with United. With competitive action taking a pause for the weekend as the Nations League begins, now appears to be a time when the club's owners are taking stock.
In our latest look at the media headlines associated with United, we have analysed how two players are being eyed to depart Old Trafford and the stance from Ineos on Erik ten Hag's future.

According to Give Me Sport, United are adamant that this will be the final season Casemiro and Christian Eriksen represent the Reds. Both players are believed to have been informed their time is coming to an end and Dan Ashworth has been presented with the task of finding youthful replacements for them.
While Galatasaray have been linked with Casemiro, it is thought they are unlikely to complete a deal before the window closes.

What MEN Sport says: It is unsurprising to hear that United want both Casemiro and Eriksen gone. Unfortunately while both have offered something during their time at Old Trafford, neither are the future of the club. The priority would be to get Casemiro off the books quickly considering his age and ultimately both are necessities needing to be done. Ashworth will certainly be earning his money to find youthful replacements for the midfield duo and United may need to bank on getting a good transfer fee in for Casemiro to help fund those deals.

According to journalist Ben Jacobs, Ten Hag's future remains in his own hands and Ineos do not have any current plans to replace him. Jacobs did note though that Gareth Southgate remained a person of interest for the United boardroom and it will not escape them that he is a free agent come the new year.

What MEN Sport says: One thing that has failed United on numerous occasions since Sir Alex Ferguson retired is the amount of strain they were receiving from the boardroom as they continuously eyed their next move. Ineos need to be different. They chose to stick with Ten Hag and as such it is good to see that they are willing to give him a chance. Three matches do not make a season and there is plenty of time to come good. The return of Leny Yoro will be a big boost for Ten Hag and fans will expect a result come 3pm a week today.

headline: Man United have one player who is ‘entitled’ to have quiet game, says Roy Keane
body: Roy Keane has come out in support of Bruno Fernandes following his underwhelming display against Liverpool.

Manchester United's start to the new season has been less than ideal, with two defeats in their first three Premier League games. A 3-0 loss at the hands of arch-rivals Liverpool on Sunday was especially bitter, and Keane wasted little time hitting out at his former side.

On the latest Stick to Football podcast episode, the ex-Red Devils captain, 53, scrutinised the team's lack of tactical clarity and accused key players of not showing up. However, he stopped short of criticising Fernandes, despite the fact the 29-year-old barely made a mark on proceedings.

"Bruno never turned up - [but] Bruno's entitled to have a quiet game," Keane told his colleagues. Earlier, Jamie Carragher had pointed out United's carelessness with possession, which contributed to a distinct lack of solidity in central areas.

Keane countered by arguing that providing stability is the defenders' responsibility, and when midfielders slip up, it's up to those behind them to extinguish any threats. "When you make mistakes you hope your defenders cover you, or your goalkeeper," he said.
"United are not really a settled team because there are still players coming to the club, and that's not an excuse, [but] when you're not at it you make mistakes."
Gary Neville then asked his former team-mate if United needed to change their playing style or simply get better at it, though Keane suggested a balanced approach. "A little bit of both," he replied.
"You're not expecting United to go long, but with United there's still an element of [mimics a player hesitating and grimacing on the ball], they don't look as if there's a flow to them."

Criticism has mounted over United's playing style under Erik ten Hag, with many accusing him of not establishing a clear in-game philosophy. The club's dismal 2023/24 campaign was partially rescued by an unexpected FA Cup final victory against Manchester City.

But after securing just three points from a possible nine in 2024/25 thus far, it looks as if last season's problems haven't gone away. Up next is a trip to Southampton after the international break before a Carabao Cup clash with League One side Barnsley, and it's fair to say both matches are in the must-win bracket.

We want your views, Reds. You can become even more involved with our Man United coverage by signing up. This will unlock a whole host of things - including joining the comments and taking part in our special Q&As, where you can speak directly to our reporters about what’s happening at Old Trafford this week and beyond.
Click here to get started.

headline: Wayne Rooney to make Manchester United return this week after latest role change
body: Wayne Rooney will return to Old Trafford for a charity match involving Manchester United legends and Celtic legends this weekend.

Saturday's fixture will be played to raise funds for the Manchester United Foundation. Rooney will be joining forces with fellow greats including Michael Carrick, Antonio Valencia, Dimitar Berbatov, Nicky Butt, and Paul Scholes.
Rooney's team will be managed by legendary United midfielder Bryan Robson alongside ex-striker Andy Cole. The Celtic team will be led by Paul Lambert.

The United Legends team regularly play fixtures but this will be Rooney's first appearance. A spokesperson said: "One of the club and country’s greatest ever players, Rooney’s name is one to transcend generations of not just United supporters, but football fans worldwide, as one of the most celebrated players to have graced the game.

"Wayne will temporarily switch the dugout for the pitch when he returns to Old Trafford as a player for the first time in seven years on 7th September – and having previously spoken of his admiration for Celtic, the Scottish side provides an apt opponent."

It comes after Rooney took over at Plymouth Argyle in his latest club management role. Rooney signed a three-year contract with the Championship club after being sacked by Birmingham City last season.

Former club captain Rooney spent 13 years with United, scoring 253 goals in 559 games, which meant he bettered Sir Bobby Charlton's previous haul of 249 goals. Former United player Valencia opened up earlier this summer on his excitement at returning to United having previously been involved in a charity match against Liverpool legends at Anfield in 2022 - a match in which Rooney did not play.

"I'm so much looking forward to it," Valencia told United's official website. "Every time that I get the invitation, I make sure that I can be there. It's going to be fun to see so many friends, the stadium and my former team-mates. I'm really anticipating it. It was really great last time, an incredible game against a historic rival of ours and just to be able to help the Foundation.

"They are why I like to come to Manchester to support this, of course, because it's a really tough job to do. What they are doing for the young people around the Manchester area, and elsewhere, I know how much work goes into it.
"I've been an ambassador for UNICEF, while I was in Manchester, and I bought my own Foundation here in Ecuador. I try to help as many kids as possible. It's something I've always been keen to do."

On facing Celtic, he added: "I have a very good memory of Scottish people and how nice they are. Not just with my teammates, not only at United but also with Wigan. And, obviously, especially the boss - Sir Alex Ferguson. I'm really expecting this to be a lot of fun."

headline: Cristiano Ronaldo shows true colours after Manchester United star Diogo Dalot's mistake
body: Cristiano Ronaldo was visibly moved to tears after scoring his landmark 900th career goal during Portugal's clash with Croatia on Thursday night.

The Al-Nassr star found the back of the net just before half-time, giving the Selecao a lead at the interval in their UEFA Nations League opener. Manchester United defender Diogo Dalot had put Roberto Martinez's team ahead earlier, but an own goal from the full-back made it 2-1 at half-time.

Ronaldo's strike marked his 131st for Portugal, adding to the 769 he has amassed at club level. This milestone followed a challenging Euro 2024 campaign where he experienced the disappointment of a penalty miss against Slovenia.

The 39 year old expertly timed his run to connect with Nuno Mendes' cross from the left and steer the ball past Croatian goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic. He then celebrated emotionally by the corner flag, surrounded by teammates who shared in the moment.

Ronaldo, prior to his strike against Croatia, had already claimed the top spot for the most goals scored in men's international football. He joins the exclusive circle of only three players that have scored over 100 times for their countries, alongside Lionel Messi and Ali Daei.

At the club level, Ronaldo's most prolific period was during his nine-year tenure at Real Madrid, where he scored an incredible 450 out of his 769 career club goals, maintaining an average that exceeded one goal per match. His tallies also include 145 goals across his two stints with Manchester United, 101 from his three years with Juventus, five goals from his early days at Sporting, and now 68 for his current side Al-Nassr.

Back in August, in a conversation with NOW, Ronaldo hinted at concluding his storied club career in Saudi Arabia: "I don't know if I will retire soon, in two or three years... but probably I will retire here at Al-Nassr," he revealed. "I'm very happy at this club, I feel good in this country too. I'm happy to play in Saudi Arabia and I want to continue."

headline: Diogo Dalot Man United escape and Rice red card sees Premier League clubs make referees demand
body: Premier League clubs have urged for greater consistency in games regarding new refereeing directives.

Before the start of the 2024/25 season, officials visited each team to detail what they would be working to tackle, including preventing the quick restart of matches and players crowding around referees.

One of the points briefed was regarding referees being particularly vigilant about punishing players delaying quick free kicks. The warning was that any offence deemed "clear, deliberate and impactful on the game" would result in a yellow card. This push for stricter officiating comes after statistics showed an increase from 118 incidents of delaying restarts in the 2022/23 season to 215 in the 2023/24 campaign.

Last weekend, Arsenal's Declan Rice became the first player to be punished by the stricter enforcement, receiving a booking that led to his sending off against Brighton. The decision led to many questioning the decision with Gunners boss Mikel Arteta left seething at full-time.

Eight separate incidents from last weekend have circulated online of players delaying a quick restart without punishment, involving Manchester United defender Diogo Dalot. There were also incidents with Marc Cucurella, Marc Guehi, Bruno Guimaraes, Joelinton, Dejan Kulusevski, Cole Palmer and Pedro Porro.

During the second half of United's 3-0 defeat to Liverpool on Sunday, Dalot fouled his opponent before delaying the restart by throwing the ball away. By the letter of the law, the defender should have received a yellow card but referee Antony Taylor chose not to punish the offence.

Dermot Gallagher and his regular Ref Watch segment on Sky Sports News every Monday has also been picked up on by fans. Gallagher, who is not part of the PGMOL team and instead works for Sky, defended referee Chris Kavanagh's decision to send off Rice for a second yellow card after he seemed to kick the ball away before Joel Veltman could take a free kick, resulting in him kicking the Arsenal midfielder.

Late last season, Wolves attempted to ban VAR amidst widespread dissatisfaction with refereeing standards and the PGMOL. Concerns among clubs existed at the end of last season regarding the PGMOL, with some raising questions about why there has not been a significant improvement in standards under Howard Webb.

This issue is likely to be discussed in future Premier League meetings - with the next scheduled for the end of September - while the PGMOL maintains that decision accuracy remains at an all-time high. The PGMOL is also fast-tracking former players into their ranks. Its officials are also on UEFA and FIFA lists and command respect across Europe.

headline: Jadon Sancho’s motivation for leaving Man Utd to join Chelsea leaves legend furious
body: Emmanuel Petit has expressed his frustration over Jadon Sancho's decision to become Chelsea's latest addition on deadline day.

Sancho - who had previously shown signs of stress under Erik ten Hag at Manchester United - once again left the club on loan this summer. After spending the latter half of last season back at Borussia Dortmund, he opted for a return to London for the rest of this season (at least).

However, former Chelsea midfielder Petit is struggling to comprehend what drove ex-Manchester City prospect Sancho to make the move to Stamford Bridge, considering the intense competition for places in west London. The Frenchman even joked about the lack of space in Chelsea's dressing room due to their active recruitment drive during the summer.

"When I saw they had signed Jadon Sancho on Deadline Day, I wondered if there was even any shirt numbers left for him," Petit told sports betting site BetVictor (via football.london). "Imagine him opening the door to the dressing room and seeing so many players they don't all fit in the same dressing room! At the training ground they must have two dressing rooms, three pitches and 12 physios.

"The club are not the only ones responsible for the situation. It also comes down to the players. How can Sancho bring himself to sign for Chelsea after what happened at Manchester United? He was loaned to Borussia Dortmund, then went back to United, and now he's off to Chelsea who have 40 or so players and he is just one of them."

Premier League and FA Cup-winner Petit continued his scathing verdict of Sancho's move and the timing of his decision. The Frenchman added: "Hasn't he had enough of moving around clubs, losing his way on the pitch and losing his confidence? Now he's at a club that has no consistency, lacking in confidence and results. If he's not there for the money, what is he there for?"

The 1998 World Cup-winner isn't alone in casting doubts over Chelsea's recent transfer strategy. Enzo Maresca's first summer in charge saw a staggering 11 new players arrive, and while just as many have departed, the club made a net loss for the third straight year.

Before Sancho's arrival was even considered, Chelsea had already splashed out approximately £100million on forward signings Pedro Neto and Joao Felix. Chelsea again recruited heavily in the area despite the presence of wingers like Cole Palmer, Christopher Nkunku, Mykhailo Mudryk, Noni Madueke, and Carney Chukwuemeka.

Sancho, 24, will turn his move to Chelsea permanent next summer in a deal worth £25m if the Blues finish 14th or higher in the Premier League. While the financial benefits of this move compared to his United terms are unclear, there's another aspect that Petit might be overlooking Sancho's long-held love for Chelsea.

"I'd probably say Frank Lampard," he told talkSPORT in 2021 when quizzed about his England football hero. "I was a Chelsea fan growing up, I can't lie! Didier Drogba and Frank Lampard were my favourite players at the time.
"I just love Frank Lampard and how he played his game; he was so direct and so composed on the ball. I like things like that."

Given his London roots and admiration for Chelsea legends, it's perhaps no shock Sancho has hooked up with the Blues. However, his immediate mission is to disprove any sceptics (like Petit) by securing a place in Maresca's lineup and underlining his dedication extends beyond financial incentives.

headline: Erik ten Hag comments suggest Manchester United could soon face transfer window regret
body: Having won two trophies in as many seasons, it is easy to understand why Erik ten Hag is gauging progression on silverware.

The Manchester United manager is proud of leading the club to the Carabao Cup and the FA Cup. The former saw Ten Hag win a trophy at the first available opportunity, while the FA Cup success against Manchester City in May kept him in a job.

United have fast become a club more prosperous in cup competitions than progressing in the Premier League. Later this month, United will kick off their Carabao Cup campaign, welcoming Barnsley to Old Trafford, before hosting FC Twente in their Europa League opener eight days later. United will have ambitions of going deep into both competitions.

United will also want to defend their FA Cup crown. In the event of reaching the final of all three competitions they face the prospect of playing 67 matches. They played 52 times last season and 62 in 2022/23. The new-look Europa League format means United will play eight games in the first phase of the competition, a rise of two, and the prospect of a play-off round would add two more fixtures in February.
Ten Hag is going to require as many options as possible to keep his squad fresh. He will also be praying United's luck changes on the injury front.

United strengthened their squad in key areas in the summer and each position is now covered with two or more options, giving Ten Hag a sufficient level of depth when everyone is fit and available. But for all of United's success in the summer, concerns have been raised about their failure to bring in a left-back. Luke Shaw has not played for United since February and Tyrell Malacia has been absent since the final day of the 2022/23 season.

In their absence, Diogo Dalot has started United's opening three league matches at left-back. Once Shaw returns from his latest lay-off, Dalot will switch to the right and compete with Noussair Mazraoui for a starting berth. The latter is also capable of operating at left-back.

But United's failure to sign a recognised left-back in the summer could prove costly given the season is going to require regular rotation. When you consider United's two senior left-backs have not played a single minute of club football between them since February, it does not paint a particularly positive picture. Shaw, as brilliant as he is when fit, simply isn't available often enough. And even once he gets himself back up to speed again, there is no chance of Ten Hag being able to rely on him game after game.

"Shaw is the best left-back in the world, he is so good," said Ten Hag, speaking last season. "But he had a very serious injury at the beginning of his career. As a result, he will never be able to play 60 games in a year."
Malacia is available even less frequently. With potentially a heavier fixture list than ever before to come, United could be left with a transfer regret.

headline: Some Man United players' futures are becoming more certain as valuation changes - Samuel Luckhurst
body: The first question at Erik ten Hag's post-match debrief on Saturday did not centre on Harry Maguire but Ten Hag made it about Maguire.

"Harry Maguire had an issue in the first half and, luckily for us, he overcame and recovered from it," Ten Hag said with relief. "You can see the second half he was up there and then he can express his leadership, he can express his defensive qualities and rest on the ball, we especially needed that in this back four."

Within eight months, Ten Hag has gone from not needing Maguire to needing him. His specific admiration for Maguire's leadership was a tad rich when he had stripped him of the captaincy but this has been a season of contradictions from the Manchester United manager.

Maguire has had a laudable campaign, especially considering his starting point. Impressionable fans in America and Ireland booed him during pre-season yet when Maguire limped off against Bayern Munich in December he was serenaded by the Old Trafford regulars.
EXCLUSIVE: Some United players delaying decisions on futures

Andre Onana was playing to the gallery in Las Vegas when he let rip at Maguire during the defeat to Borussia Dortmund. At Bournemouth, Onana offered his teammate a high five during a tactical timeout.

Maguire has not been this valued at United in almost three years. His strengths were more obvious when he was absent for the 2020-21 run-in as United sieved nine goals in five matches. Maguire recovered from injury to earn a place in the European Championship team of the tournament.

The 31-year-old is arguably enjoying his best preparation for a major international finals. He was not visible in the training imagery United published on Tuesday but there is ample time to recover for Sunday's FA Cup semi-final against Coventry City.

At last year's semi-final, Maguire was reeling from his role in United's two-legged collapse to Sevilla in the Europa League quarter-final. Without him on the pitch, United led 2-0. With Maguire on the pitch, they lost 5-0. He did not see Erik Lamela coming when his blind pass was intercepted and Youssef En-Nesyri got the fiesta started in the second leg.

Maguire was suspended for the Cup semi-final against Brighton three days later. He still travelled and loitered during the stoppages. Some keyboard warriors attempted to vilify him for not engaging with the players as much as matchday captain Bruno Fernandes. Maguire was never going to pull rank and pull his kit on like John Terry.

This weekend, Maguire is as certain to start at Wembley as the inheritor of his armband (if fit). United's other four senior centre halves are sidelined for the rest of the month, two are out of contract in June and Victor Lindelof is next year.

Gutting an entire department can leave you without organs. United let Rio Ferdinand, Nemanja Vidic and Patrice Evra go in the summer of 2014 and only brought in one out-and-out defender in Marcos Rojo. The memory of Rojo once caused Ryan Giggs, United's assistant manager back then, to shake his head.

Louis van Gaal thought Chris Smalling, Phil Jones and Jonny Evans would be robust enough. Tyler Blackett and Paddy McNair were drafted in. Daley Blind had to be rebranded as a centre back the following season.
Maguire's contract has a maximum expiry date of 2026. He had one foot out of the door in the summer but he is now likely to stay. He is fit and not as urgent or obvious a sale as Lindelof.

United still have a goal difference of -1 and the wall in front of their back four is made of plaster. Casemiro is on his last legs but would still start on one leg, such is the peripheral status of Sofyan Amrabat. The Moroccan has started one game in four months.

Amrabat will be returned to Fiorentina and the retirement home of the Saudi Pro League is calling for Casemiro. Christian Eriksen has another year left on his contract but has started once this calendar year.

Scott McTominay's contract length is the same as Maguire's and he might have been elsewhere by now had United not encountered a problem in Houston with Kobbie Mainoo's ankle injury. Selling academy graduate McTominay would represent pure profit with the profitability and sustainability rules.

United valued McTominay at £40million last summer and he is enjoying his best goalscoring season. There is also the cachet of representing Scotland at the Euros. His value is far greater now, possibly too great for an ambitious Premier League club to table a bid.

Anthony Martial is going and Jadon Sancho, Antony, Mason Greenwood, Amad and Facundo Pellistri could or should go. Rasmus Hojlund and Alejandro Garnacho are the only forwards assured of returning to Carrington when the summer transfer window closes.
However mutually beneficial a departure would be for club and player, there may not be a market for Marcus Rashford. 'Can't' is on the Ineos compass of words they don't like, though.
Some would argue United can't sell Maguire.

headline: Jason Wilcox will encounter familiar Manchester United transfer problem with no obvious solution
body: A figure who deals with recruitment elsewhere in the Premier League succinctly summed up the problem that Jason Wilcox will face when he tries to cut deals for Manchester United this summer. "When United call they get quoted £40million for a player available for £10million."

Recruitment chiefs at Old Trafford will understand that assessment. Those working at the club have long referred to what is called the 'United tax'. As soon as they enquire about a player the price rockets, purely because they are Manchester United.

They encountered it in Erik ten Hag's first window, when then football director John Murtough enquired about a young player with the knowledge that another club were close to a deal for £15million. That will be £28million please. "You're Manchester United, you've got loads of money," Murtough was told.

The irony here is, of course, that they really do not. Not in terms of transfer budget anyway. They are sailing close to the wind when it comes to the Premier League's Profit and Sustainability Rules (PSR) and having missed out on Champions League football they will see that war chest shrink even more.

That reality is unlikely to stop clubs from trying to profit from United. A history of overpaying for transfers has contributed to that tax, let's not forget. Real Madrid and Ajax were delighted with the £70million and £85million they received for Casemiro and Antony a couple of years ago.
