body: Manchester United successfully managed to strengthen their midfield in the summer transfer window with the late signing of Manuel Ugarte.

The Red Devils were linked with a number of midfielders throughout the summer but Ugarte was always Erik ten Hag's priority target. A move for the Uruguay international took a number of turns before a deal worth £50.5million with add-ons.

United now have a variety of options in the middle of the park with the likes of Kobbie Mainoo and Bruno Fernandes mainstays. However, injury to Mason Mount and consistent problems for Casemiro means problems remain.

Ten Hag plays a midfield three with Fernandes often joining the forward line. However, United are often short when the Portugal playmaker is unavailable. Fortunately, despite the transfer window closing a week ago, sporting director Dan Ashworth could still register an attacking midfielder.

United have reportedly been offered former Lille star and Turkey international Yusuf Yazici. The playmaker is currently without a club after leaving the French club at the end of June and it's understood that he's been offered to a number of Premier League clubs.

HITC have claimed that United remain keen to bolster Ten Hag's midfield after Yazici was offered to them on a free transfer. Tottenham, Aston Villa and Newcastle have all been notified of his availability.

The position may not be one that United are desperate for but it could help Ten Hag and Fernandes. Since joining the club in 2020, the 29-year-old has played 237 games, missing just 15 games. Behind him, United have lacked a player to take the load off him.

A problem Ten Hag is faced with is resting Fernandes in cup fixtures to ensure he's fresh for the Premier League. Signing Yazici outside the transfer window to add some depth in that position could be a crucial decision by Ashworth.

headline: Roy Keane has already told Man United what to do with Antony after transfer comments
body: Roy Keane has already offered his verdict on Antony's future amid reports linking him with a move away from Manchester United.
The Brazilian has failed to live up to expectations since completing a move to Old Trafford in 2022. Antony has scored 11 goals and provided just five assists in 83 appearances for the Reds.
Recent reports have claimed that Turkish club Fenerbahce are interested in a loan move for the 24-year-old. It is said that former United boss Jose Mourinho is keen to sign the winger.

On an episode of Stick To Football in December last year, former United captain Keane was asked to decide whether to ‘keep’ or ‘ditch’ a current squad member, or state that they were on their ‘last straw’. Gary Neville read out each United first-team member with fellow panellists Jamie Carragher and Ian Wright also asked to give their verdict.

Going through the list of players, Keane decided that 10 members of the squad are not up to standard and should be offloaded going forward. Of those currently at the club, he named Antony, Victor Lindelof, Harry Maguire, Diogo Dalot, Jonny Evans, and Christian Eriksen as falling under this category.

Earlier this year Antony's agent, Junior Pedroso, commented on a potential transfer for his client. He said: “I see reports about a potential exit on loan. Antony’s plan is clear: Manchester United. He wants to stay, he’s only focused on Man United. We already spoke about that with the club.”

Meanwhile, Keane said Andre Onana, Luke Shaw, Aaron Wan-Bissaka and Scott McTominay were all on their final chance, as was manager Erik ten Hag. When it came to Rashford, Keane admitted he was on the fence. “I’m not sure about Marcus [Rashford],” Keane said. “The whole package – personality, his mood swings.

"He’s a talented player, but if you’re not going to work hard, and he’s having these dips every now and again, there’s all this talk about his confidence, off the field stuff. Just turn up every week and do the business. Marcus is 26. When’s the penny going to drop for him?”

headline: Cristiano Ronaldo breaks down in tears during Portugal match after scoring 900th goal of career
body: Cristiano Ronaldo was visibly overcome with emotion as he bagged his 900th career goal during Portugal's clash with Croatia on Thursday in a poignant milestone for the veteran striker.

The Al-Nassr star fired home just before half-time, driving the Selecao ahead in their UEFA Nations League opening fixture. Former Manchester United team-mate Diogo Dalot had initially given Roberto Martinez's team an edge, but it was Ronaldo's landmark strike that stole the headlines, despite Dalot's own goal which adjusted the half-time score to 2-1.

His latest tally marks Ronaldo's 131st international goal, supplementing the impressive 769 club-level goals he's notched up over his illustrious career. The goal was a redeeming moment following a vexing Euro 2024 campaign wherein he witnessed a penalty saved against Slovenia.

At 39, Ronaldo's precision was unerring as he met Nuno Mendes' cross to slot the ball beyond Croatia's keeper Dominik Livakovic. His subsequent celebration at the corner flag was a blend of joy and tears, surrounded by his teammates' support.

Leading into the match with Croatia, Ronaldo had disclosed to former United colleague Rio Ferdinand his intentions to pursue the 1,000-goal mark, asserting his immediate goal was "Soon I will do 900 and after that it will be 1,000". Queried on the age he expects to achieve this ambition, Ronaldo confidently responded: "41, I don't know. If I don't have injuries, that is most important, I want that. My challenge is to reach 1,000 goals, with one difference all the goals that I score will have video. So I can prove that," reports the Mirror.

Ronaldo, having surpassed Ali Daei's record, has established himself as the all-time leading scorer for international men's goals and is part of an elite group of centurions that includes Messi and Daei.

During his time at Real Madrid, Ronaldo netted an impressive 450 goals over nine years, maintaining an average of more than one goal per fixture. His stints with Manchester United saw him score 145 goals, coupled with 101 at Juventus over three seasons, five in his early days at Sporting, and currently 68 for Al-Nassr.

headline: Lisandro Martinez repeats Erik ten Hag message and reveals Sir Alex Ferguson talks at Man United
body: Lisandro Martinez has echoed Erik ten Hag by referring to his two trophy triumphs in as many seasons as a sign of progress at Manchester United, while acknowledging there is still room for growth.

The United boss was keen to relay his League Cup and FA Cup successes in defence of his tenure to journalists following Sunday’s 3-0 drubbing by Liverpool, having seen his side lose two of their three opening games this season.

Some United supporters feel unsatisfied by the Dutchman’s two-year reign so far, despite his silverware haul. The club recorded their lowest Premier League finish last season after finishing bottom of their Champions League group and producing a flimsy defence of their League Cup title.
Speaking after the defeat to Liverpool, Ten Hag said: “Listen, we won, the last two years, behind Manchester City, the most trophies in English football, so we performed already the last two seasons.
“And, yes, also this year, we want to win and we want to win trophies. And so I'm quite confident we will build to this. And that is what I did the last 11 years.
“So just be patient, waiting. We will work on the process and we have to improve the process. And we will aim for our next targets and we will go for trophies.”

United were plagued by injury setbacks last season, with Martinez one of those suffering persistent problems. The Argentine only played a total of 14 club matches last term having sustained three separate significant issues.

While speaking to native media outlet La Nacion ahead of Argentina’s World Cup qualifiers this international break, the defender admitting to feeling “insecure” about his constant injuries, outling how such a spate can “destroy your head”.

But the 26-year-old, who says he is "grateful" for what he learned through his time out, is nevertheless on board with Ten Hag’s message of progress. Detailing his two years so far at the club, he said: “When I set foot in United's training centre in Carrington, I felt something special.
“‘We're going to win here,’ that's what I felt. Like electricity, a strong energy of glory... something that motivated me a lot. 'This is a place to win,' I told myself.

“Well, we've already won two very important titles in two seasons, but we have to keep growing to reach our goal, which is to become what Manchester has always been, one of the very great teams, one of the best in the world.”
Martinez completed a personal redemption arc when he played 73 minutes of this year’s shock FA Cup win over Manchester City, having been ruled out of the 2023 edition due to injury.
He revealed that the trip to Wembley was one occasion through which he managed to speak with Sir Alex Ferguson, who himself lifted five FA Cups during his reign.
“I have met Ferguson three or four times,” Martinez revealed. “Ferguson is the God of Manchester. He is a person who gave a lot to the club and who continues to give because he remains connected.

“Now, the new owners have also included him. When [Argentina] won the World Cup we spoke a little, he congratulated me. Later, also when we won the Carabao and the FA Cup - he is a legend of world football and I respect people's privacy…
“Of course I would like to be able to talk to him, actually listen to him, but I would not dare to invade his space.”

headline: Man United tipped for stunning Europa League run after rule change and squad decision
body: A supercomputer has predicted Manchester United to win this season’s Europa League on penalties, having based its calculations on the probable outcome of each match.

Like the Champions League, this season’s edition features an extra two group games within one big league table amid fixtures against teams of varying co-efficient ranking. Final positions determine which teams play each other in the play-off and last-16 rounds and all the way through to the final.

This seeded draw has enabled AI technology from Grosvenor Sport to work out who might play who when, as well as the likely scoreline outcome of each contest based on form, team strength and betting odds. A 'level of randomness’ has been thrown in to reflect possible upsets, so that the top seed does not always necessarily win every game.
This process, based on current information available, is done 1,000 times, from which the supercomputer composes a final league table for the initial round of group fixtures.

In said league phase, United are due to face FC Twente at home before Porto and Fenerbahce away ahead of meetings with PAOK and Bodo/Glimt at Old Trafford. United then travel to Viktoria Plzen before facing Rangers at home ahead of a final trip to Steaua Bucharest.

The predicted table shows United - who have confirmed their Europa League squad - finishing seventh and thereby within the top eight teams who automatically advance to the last-16. Lyon are put top with Porto second and Lazio third.

Tottenham have been placed 11th, meaning they would have to go through the two-legged play-off round. Meanwhile, Rangers also are required to move through the play-offs with the supercomputer depicting them as facing Spurs in that round and losing.

Ange Postecoglou’s men are then triumphant against Midtjylland and Union SG but bow out to United in the semi-finals. Whether Erik ten Hag is still in situ or not, the supercomputer crowns United champions over finalists Athletic Club on penalties after drawing 2-2 after extra time.

The new format has also done away with teams dropping down from the Champions League to the Europa League, meaning that predictions become somewhat simpler - albeit the seeded draw based on final league standing make for many knockout permutations.

headline: Ugarte role, Rashford dropped, Yoro decision - Manchester United strongest Europa League XI
body: It’s not long until Manchester United return to European action with the new UEFA Europa League just around the corner.

United discovered their opponents in the draw last week with the club facing eight fixtures in the league stage of the competition. They kick off on Wednesday 25 September when they take on FC Twente at Old Trafford, where they will look to get off to a winning start.

Ahead of the start of the league phase, United’s 25-man squad for the competition has now been announced on the UEFA website. All the summer signings Joshua Zirkzee, Leny Yoro, Matthijs de Ligt, Noussair Mazeaoui, and Manuel Ugarte have been included.
The 25-man squad consists of an A-list. The club also have a B list that consists of club-trained players born after January 1, 2003.

The likes of Alejandro Garnacho, Kobbie Mainoo, and Toby Collyer all qualify for the list and therefore do not need to be counted in the 25-man A list. They all will still be available for the competition.
Tyrell Malacia and Casemiro are among those to be registered on the A-list. But, taking a look at the squad available, what could Erik ten Hag’s strongest team look like?

While he is currently sidelined with a fractured foot, when he returns to fitness, new centre-back Yoro could go straight into the starting XI partnering Lisandro Martinez. Left-back Luke Shaw returning from injury will also provide a boost to Ten Hag with Diogo Dalot currently covering the position.

Another new signing in Manuel Ugarte could add more solidity in midfield alongside Mainoo. Amad impressed in his minutes off the bench against Liverpool, and while it’s not his natural side, given Marcus Rashford’s current form he could be given the shout.

A third injury boost would also impact Ten Hag’s selection for the competition. Striker Rasmus Hojlund is yet to play this season, but could get the shout ahead of Joshua Zirkzee after scoring five times in six Champions League games last season.
Manchester United strongest Europa League XI: Onana; Mazraoui, Yoro, Martinez, Shaw; Mainoo, Ugarte; Garnacho, Fernandes, Amad; Hojlund.

headline: Man United star Antony makes true feelings clear after transfer decision made
body: Manchester United winger Antony has been celebrating his two year anniversary since making his debut for the club, despite reports that Fenerbahce are in talks to sign him. After another disappointing season at Old Trafford, the Brazilian is one of those being spoken possibly leaving still this summer.
Although the British transfer window shut on Friday, there are some countries that can still do business. One of those is Turkey, and clubs have been taking advantage.

Already, Galatasaray have signed Victor Osimhen on a loan from Napoli after he failed to secure an exit. For those are attempting to clear out their squad, it provides a last chance to recoup fees and offer first-team football in Europe.

Antony, who only scored one Premier League goal last season, only notching a single assist as well from his 29 total appearances and 15 starts, is one of those in need of a change of luck at Old Trafford. Erik ten Hag has only used him once in 2024/25 so far and even that was via a brief cameo off the bench.

With United favouring the development of Alejandro Garnacho and Amad, Antony has dropped down the pecking order and is out of form and favour. Far from being a popular name with supporters, the £85million man was reportedly one of many that United would consider selling.

Under Jose Mourinho, Fenerbahce are the latest side to be linked. It is claimed that the former United boss is keen to get Antony on loan for the season. The Mirror claims that he wishes to remain though, with ambitions to turn things around and become a success.

Earlier this year his agent, Junior Pedroso, said: “I see reports about a potential exit on loan. Antony’s plan is clear: Manchester United. He wants to stay, he’s only focused on Man United. We already spoke about that with the club.”
Ten Hag has also stuck by his man. “He [Antony] certainly showed that potential in the first month: he scored three times in his first three games,” the Dutchman said.
“After that it became more difficult, last season was not good. But I am still convinced that he has the potential to play at this club.”

Antony himself now appears to be channelling that energy. Reposting United's throwback Instagram image of Antony's debut and first goal two years ago, the player made his emotions clear. He added two heart emojis to the post which included pictures with him celebrating by tapping the club badge.

headline: Why Kobbie Mainoo and Alejandro Garnacho aren't included in Man United Europa League squad list
body: Kobbie Mainoo, Toby Collyer and Alejandro Garnacho have been left off Manchester United's initial Europa League squad submitted to UEFA earlier this week.

Every club in the group stages of the Champions League, Europa League and Conference League had to submit their squads to the governing body by 11pm on Tuesday and United's 25-man squad has been revealed today. Mainoo, Collyer and Garnacho are the stand-out names not included but all three have missed the cut because they are classed as 'club-trained players' and as a result can be added to the B list of players ahead of the opening game.

United begin their eight-game league schedule against FC Twente at Old Trafford on Wednesday, September 25 and they will be able to add players who qualify for the B list to the squad up to the day before that fixture, so Mainoo, Collyer and Garnacho will still feature in the competition this season.

Submissions to UEFA for squads are limited to 25 players and United have filled their A list, which is why Mainoo and Garnacho have been left off for now. United included 21-year-old goalkeeper Dermot Mee and also named Leny Yoro, 18, and Harry Amass, 17, in the squad.

While a 25-man Premier League squad submission allows clubs to list all under-21s on a B list, under UEFA rules only players that are aged under 21 and have spent two years at the club qualify. So while Mainoo, Collyer and Garnacho qualify for the B list, Amass and Yoro don't as they haven't spent two years at the club. Yoro signing from Lille this summer and Amass arriving from Watford in 2023.

UEFA rules also state a club must have eight locally-trained players in their squad, with at least four academy graduates. United fill those slots with Mee, Tom Heaton, Jonny Evans and Marcus Rashford.

headline: 'Played an important role' - Manchester United senior departure confirmed by Dan Ashworth and Sir Dave Brailsford
body: Andy O'Boyle will leave his role as deputy football director at Manchester United next week after Dan Ashworth and Sir Dave Brailsford confirmed his departure.

O'Boyle is leaving United after just over two years in his role and although he played a key part in the transition to a new football structure under Ineos, his responsibilities are now overlapping with sporting director Ashworth and technical director Jason Wilcox.

One of his final acts at United was to play a major part in drawing up plans for the £50m redevelopment at Carrington, with work now underway to transform the club's training ground and deliver improved facilities in time for the 2025/26 season.

He will leave the club at the end of next week (Friday, September 13) and his departure was officially confirmed to staff in an email sent by Ashworth and Brailsford on Wednesday, in which they praised the "significant contribution" O'Boyle had made to the football department.

In the email, seen by the Manchester Evening News, Ashworth and Brailsford said: "In particular, we would like to thank Andy for the help and support he has provided to both of us and the Ineos team during the first few months of our involvement with the club and during our first transfer window.
"He has also played an important role in the redevelopment of Carrington, and his contribution has been key in planning the world-class training facilities we will have here next season."

O'Boyle arrived at United in May 2022, leaving a position as the Premier League's head of elite performance to take up the role as John Murtough's deputy. He had a particular focus on data, sports science, medical and the women's team.

Murtough left United in April and at this point O'Boyle took on more responsibility and formed a particularly close working relationship with Brailsford, often sitting next to Ineos' director of sport in the Old Trafford directors' box.

But gradually Sir Jim Ratcliffe has put the structure he wanted in place. Chief executive Omar Berrada and Ashworth both started in July, while Wilcox began work in April. As the MEN revealed yesterday, interim director of recruitment Christopher Vivell has signed a contract to remain in place until at least February.

O'Boyle's job title meant he was deputy to a position that no longer existed and with the Ineos hires now settled at the club, it has been decided the time is right for O'Boyle to move on. It is understood he will now pursue a leadership role elsewhere in the game.

headline: Manchester United receive injury boost with exciting youngster set to return
body: Manchester United's exciting youngster Shea Lacey could return to action after the international break.
The Manchester Evening News understands Lacey has been sidelined with a muscle injury but has made progress in his recovery and will be in contention to play after the break.
Lacey is in contention to feature for the Under-18s against Newcastle on Saturday, September 14 and it's thought he will be carefully handled and eased back into action.
Followers of the academy are looking forward to Lacey's return, but United will not rush the youngster, who last made an appearance in April, back from his injury.
The winger is one of the most highly-regarded talents in the academy and signed a professional contract with United immediately after celebrating his 17th birthday.

Only the most highly-rated prospects in the academy are given professional terms when they turn 17 - the age when you can sign a pro deal - and Lacey has long been considered one of the leading lights in his age group, which is why he was tied down at the earliest opportunity.

There are high hopes at United for Lacey and he took part in first-team training at Carrington last season. In the last few years, footage of the creative youngster playing for United's academy has gone viral on social media and such clips have amassed thousands of views.
Lacey was born in Merseyside and comes from a family of Liverpool fans, but he's a United supporter and grew up idolising multi-Ballon d'Or winner Lionel Messi.
He has predominately played on the right wing, but coaches in the academy like to challenge youngsters in different positions across the attack and Lacey is versatile.
There have been comparisons made between Lacey and Phil Foden and, just like the Manchester City star, Lacey's long-term future could be as an attacking midfielder.
The 17-year-old has represented England at Under-15 and Under-16 level.

headline: Man United starlet lays down marker with stunning 36-minute hat-trick for Wales
body: Manchester United striker Louie Bradbury has scored a 29-minute hat-trick on debut for the Wales under-17 national team during an international friendly against Gibraltar in Spain.

Bradbury, who turns 16 this month, opened the scoring in the seventh minute before doubling their advantage 11 minutes later and the United starlet added a third in the 36th minute. Everton winger Shea Pita fired in a fourth soon after half-time.

The newly-appointed Wales head coach Wayne Hatswell subsequently made several changes with the hour mark approaching, with Bradbury substituted. Southampton winger Oli Newman was one of those to come on, scoring the fifth late to make it a 5-0 win.
READ MORE:Chido Obi-Martin to United transfer latest as manager offers update after Arsenal exit
READ MORE:Who is Sekou Kone? Meet United's new wonderkid signing who has secret Tottenham Hotspur link

After the match, Bradbury shared on social media that it was his first international hat-trick. The striker played for the Wales under-15s during the 2022/23 season, debuting a month before turning 13 and scoring twice in five appearances, both in a friendly against South Korea in Croatia. Bradbury featured 11 times for the James Rowberry-coached under-16 last season, scoring three goals and assisting another.

The teenager has now scored eight goals in ten starts for his country. Wales also face Qatar on Friday as their preparations continue for the start of their European Under-17 Championship qualification campaign in November, when they will play Italy, Norway and San Marino in Group 9 during the Round 1.

United signed Bradbury from Shrewsbury Town in February 2023, where he spent the previous six-and-a-half years after being spotted playing for the Welsh club Corwen. The striker played for the Reds' under-15s and under-16s last season, sharing on social media that he scored 40 goals in his first full campaign at the academy.

Bradbury then spent this pre-season with the under-18s, playing at the SuperCupNI, previously known as the Milk Cup. That saw him link up with fellow Wales youth international Gabriele Biancheri, an under-19s national team player who United signed from Cardiff City around the same time Bradbury joined.

headline: New Man United signing explains reason for summer transfer as clear promise made
body: New Manchester United signing Dominique Janssen says the club's "big ambitions" helped convince her to make the switch to Marc Skinner's side and believes the Reds' FA Cup success last term will drive them on to more silverware.

Janssen joined United on a three-year deal with the option of an additional 12 months earlier in the summer following the expiration of her contract with Wolfsburg. The Netherlands defender returns to the Women’s Super League (WSL) having previously spent four seasons at Arsenal, with whom she won the league title, the FA Cup and two League Cups.

Reflecting on her decision to join the Reds in her first interview with the club, Janssen said: "I knew a little bit (about United) and their fan base is like crazy, it's really nice to get to know them and to see how the club has developed and also to see where we can go with the team.

"The club have big ambitions. The growth they have been making the past six years since they have started has also been really good. Of course there will also be some bumps in the road which I heard from the girls as well that last season was maybe was not the easiest season.

"But it's about knowing the up and downs are just part of the journey and it's so exciting to see where we can go in the next few years. That's what also drew me to the club, the potential we have in the next few years. I want to help the club and I want to do it together with the girls."

Last season was a disappointing one for United as they finished fifth in the WSL, winning just 10 of their 22 league games. However, the Reds did manage to secure the club's first major women's trophy by beating Tottenham Hotspur to the FA Cup and Janssen believes this will spur Skinner's side on to achieving more success next term.
"That's the goal," she said. "I'm hungry for more trophies and I think also they got last year the first trophy, so I think they're hungry for more trophies as well."

The defender added: "I think it has changed a lot. I have looked a little bit at the games and seeing how things are going and you see that the league is very competitive. You need to be at the top of your game every single weekend. You cannot play at 80 per cent because even the teams that are lower in the table can still beat you."

United will kick off their new WSL campaign against West Ham United on September 21 and Janssen is relishing the chance to get her first taste of representing United at Old Trafford. She said: "I think first of all just playing at Old Trafford, obviously it's called the Theatre of Dreams so I'm very excited to play there and see how many people come as well."

headline: Man United star makes trophy vow after beating Man City and Chelsea rivals to 'unbelievable' award
body: England midfielder Grace Clinton says her aim is to win trophies with Manchester United after being voted PFA Young Player of the Year.

The 21-year-old joined the Reds from Everton in 2022 though she is yet to make a competitive appearance for the club, having since enjoyed loan spells at both Bristol City and Tottenham Hotspur. Clinton excelled for the latter last term, scoring four goals and assisting four others in 20 Women's Super League (WSL) appearances and playing an integral role in Spurs’ charge to their first ever Women’s FA Cup final, though she was ineligible to play against her parent club and eventual victors United at Wembley.

Her impressive form saw her receive her first senior England call up earlier this year. She made her first full start against Austria after two appearances off the bench, and duly made an impact with her first international goal in a 7-2 win for the Lionesses.

Clinton impressed so much at Tottenham that the club were keen to make her stay in the capital permanent. “She cannot stay because she’s not a part of us next year," manager Robert Vilahamn told The Athletic in April. "But if you ask me if I want to buy her, there would be a high potential I want to do that."

However United boss Skinner has always been unequivocal in his stance on the 21-year-old, insisting that her long-term future lies in Manchester. "All I hear is Tottenham want to keep Grace, of course they want to keep Grace," he said when quizzed on the club's plans for Clinton back in May. "She's a fantastic player.

"We don't get the credit that we identified her qualities at Everton, we brought her to Manchester United, gave her six months, sent her on loan at Bristol – she got experience. She then went on loan to Tottenham to get more experience. I don't think people recognise that – there is a plan for each individual we bring into the club.
"With Grace, it's absolutely worked. I want to bring her back to the club and be part of what we're doing because I think she has a huge say in how we'll play."

And Clinton has now voiced her commitment to the Reds, insisting her ambition is to add more silverware to the club's collection. "To go to Tottenham and get confidence was just amazing," she said at the start-studded awards ceremony on Tuesday night. "And to improve obviously personally. The aim is always to win trophies with Manchester United."

On her award, Clinton added: “It’s such an honour to be voted by the unbelievable players that play in this league. It’s the best league in the world. “To go out on loan, learning as a young player and being recognized is lovely. I’ve played with confidence and when you play with that then you see the best version of a player. Tottenham have been a massive part of my journey, and I can’t thank them enough. Goals and visualisation are important to me but most of all just enjoying playing. If I’m enjoying myself then I play my best football.”

Clinton also featured in the PFA Women's Team of the Year, alongside Manchester City stars Khadija 'Bunny' Shaw, Yui Hasegawa, Lauren Hemp, Khiara Keating, Alex Greenwood, Laia Aleixandri. She beat out a host of talented players to earn the award with Lauren James, Aggie Beever-Jones, Khiara Keating, Maya Le Tissier and Jess Park among the names on the Top Six shortlist.

headline: Man United have already made history but hard work is only just beginning
body: With a deft back-post finish, Lizzie Arnot wrote her name into the annals of Manchester United history. The date was August 19, 2018 and the Scotland international ensured the Reds' long-awaited renaissance began in style by netting a last-gasp winner against bitter rivals Liverpool in the League Cup.

The setting - in front of just 829 fans at an overcast Prenton Park - belied the enormity of the occassion. This was United's first competitive game in 13 years, their first competitive outing since the Glazer regime opted to disband their senior women's team after deeming it not to be part of the club's "core business".

The team was peppered with familar faces. Alex Greenwood, now captain of Manchester City, teed up Arnot to score the winner. Lauren James, who returned to childhood club Chelsea for what was - in 2021 - a British record fee, started in midfield, while current United stars Ella Toone, Millie Turner and Leah Galton also featured.
"For a team that has only been together for six weeks they weathered the storm quite well," manager Casey Stoney told BBC Radio 5 Live after the game.

"I recruited from the second tier, they've stepped up and shown they are more than capable of playing a level above that. There's no pressure from the club to get promotion but these players want to be playing in the top flight. They're history makers now."

In spite of Stoney's measured assessment of United's ambitions, the Reds did achieve promotion at the first time of asking, subsequently finishing fourth in their first season in the Women's Super League (WSL). And now, just six years on from that League Cup victory over Liverpool, United are a card-carrying member of the top flight's elite.

Stoney's departure in the summer of 2021 was a blow but her replacement, former Birmingham City boss Marc Skinner, has presided over the most successful period in the club's history. In 2022/23, the Reds took the title race to the final day, posting a club-record points tally in the process while also reaching the FA Cup final.

Last term, despite a disappointing fifth-place finish in the WSL, United beat Tottenham Hotspur to the FA Cup trophy; a reality which would have seemed inconceivable on that momentous afternoon at Prenton Park more than half a decade ago.

While the Reds have come a tremendously long way since then, it is fair to say this summer has not been without its challenges. First came the revelataion that Skinner had been handed a one-year contract extension - a decision which was not universally popular with the United fanbase.

Then came the exodus of some of the club's biggest stars. England goalkeeper Mary Earps left to join Paris Saint-Germain (PSG), citing United's transitional state and her own ambition to compete for more silverware as her chief motivating factors. Club captain Katie Zelem also departed on a free transfer, as did fan-favourite striker Lucia Garcia.

All of this unfolded has against the backdrop of Sir Jim Ratcliffe's barely concealed apathy towards Skinner's side. The INEOS chief gave a tone-deaf interview to Bloomberg, in which he conceded plans for the women's team were "TBC".

This was swiftly followed by United Women being ousted from their state-of-the-art Carrington training facility to make way for the men's team while their own building gets a revamp, though it is understood Skinner and his players will still have access to all the necessary facilities.

Still, the emergence of reports citing concern from the Professional Footballers Association (PFA) and of agents' apparent unwillingness to throw their players into the maelstrom that is Manchester United have been concerning.

That said, the Reds have recruited shrewdly in the transfer market, with the acquisition of Brighton & Hove Albion striker Elisabeth Terland and Swedish defender Anna Sandberg, in particular, inspiring excitement, while the appointment of Dan Ashworth as sporting director inspires hope of tangible change at the club.

“Delivering a successful women’s team and a thriving, productive academy are both key objectives of my job, and I have a strong background in both areas," Ashworth said in an open letter to supporters last month.

"Women’s football was an important part of my remit in past roles with Newcastle United, Brighton & Hove Albion and the FA, and it will be the same at Manchester United. Women’s football is arguably the most exciting area of growth in the global game, and we want to be part of that.
“Last season’s FA Cup win was a fantastic landmark as our first major women’s trophy, and how we want to build on that with Marc, his staff and the players."

Indeed, six years on from that win over Liverpool, United now have all the ingredients in place to be truly successful. The Reds may already have made history in the years since their reformation but, with the WSL set to be more competitive than ever next term, it is clear the hard work is only just beginning.

headline: Dan Ashworth makes encouraging Man United gesture after Sir Jim Ratcliffe admission
body: Dan Ashworth has met with Manchester United Women's players after a turbulent summer for Marc Skinner's side.

United have come in for criticism of late number after a number of high-profile players, including England goalkeeper Mary Earps and captain Katie Zelem, were allowed to leave the club on free transfers, while co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe sparked controversy when he admitted plans for the women's team were "TBC".

Fan frustration was further compounded when it emerged Skinner's side were set to be moved out of their state-of-the-art training facility to accommodate the men's team while a £50m refurbishment of their Carrington facilities was underway.

However, Ashworth's long-awaited arrival from Newcastle United last month has offered some cause for optimism, with the sporting director having previously been a huge advocate for the growth of the women's game during his time with the Magpies and in his previous role at Brighton & Hove Albion. And the 53-year-old has now met with Skinner and his players as they ramp up their pre-season preparations at St George's Park.

Pictures shared on the club's website show Ashworth giving a speech to the women's first-team squad and shaking hands with stars such as Ella Toone and Millie Turner. This comes after he outlined his vision for the Reds in an open letter to supporters.

“Delivering a successful women’s team and a thriving, productive academy are both key objectives of my job, and I have a strong background in both areas," Ashworth said last month. "Women’s football was an important part of my remit in past roles with Newcastle United, Brighton & Hove Albion and the FA, and it will be the same at Manchester United.

"Women’s football is arguably the most exciting area of growth in the global game, and we want to be part of that. Last season’s FA Cup win was a fantastic landmark as our first major women’s trophy, and how we want to build on that with Marc, his staff and the players."
United finished fifth in the Women's Super League (WSL) last term and won the Women's FA Cup. They will get their new campaign underway against West Ham at Old Trafford on Saturday, September 22.

headline: Manchester United confirm 'insane' summer transfer as overhaul continues
body: Manchester United have confirmed the signing of Canada international Simi Awujo on a three-year deal.

The 20-year-old midfielder joins the Reds from the United States collegiate system, where she represented the University of Southern California’s USC Trojans. Awujo made her senior international debut for Canada at 18-years-old and has 19 caps for her country to date, reaching the quarter-finals of this summer’s Paris 2024 Olympic games.

Reflecting on her move to Manchester, Awujo said: “To say that I’m a professional footballer for Manchester United is insane. I’m so excited for the season ahead, what the future holds here and just to be a red devil. I cannot wait to play in front of the great Manchester United fans.”

Manager Marc Skinner added: “Simi is an exciting young talent who we are delighted has chosen to continue her football journey with us here at Manchester United. Our wonderful fans can expect a midfielder with international pedigree, who will only develop further in our competitive English game.”

Awujo is United's fifth signing of the summer following the arrivals of Dominique Janssen, Melvine Malard, Elisabeth Terland and Anna Sandber. The Reds finished fifth in the Women's Super League (WSL) last term and won the Women's FA Cup. They will get their new campaign underway against West Ham at Old Trafford on Saturday, September 22.
